questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with hirsutism and masculinization. Which of the following hormones of the adrenal cortex is the likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Hirsutism and masculinization in a female suggest excessive androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA).

Adrenogenital syndrome is due to an adrenocortical tumor secreting excessive quantities of androgens that cause intense masculinizing effects.  In boys, it presents as precocious puberty. In women, virile characteristics develop, including:

  • Growth of a beard
  • Deeper voice
  • Masculine distribution of hair on the body and the pubis and
  • Growth of the clitoris

The excretion of 17-ketosteroids (which are derived from androgens) in the urine maybe 10 to 15 times elevated. This finding can be used in diagnosing the disease.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient was found to have a PSA of 5.6 ng/ml on routine examination and was advised to undergo a TRUS-guided transrectal biopsy. What is the standard biopsy template?

TRUS-Trans Rectal Ultrasound Scan
questions.solution:
The standard biopsy template usually includes 12 biopsies taken from six areas.

Patients who have either an elevated total PSA level (i.e. over 2.5 - 4.0 ng/ml) or abnormal findings on digital rectal examination (DRE) or both are advised to undergo TRUS-guided biopsy of the prostate.

The standard biopsy template involves 12 core biopsies with a spring-loaded biopsy instrument.

Site of biopsy: The tissue is usually obtained from the base, mid, and apex regions, medially and laterally from the left and right sides.

Patients are asked to stop anticoagulants to prevent bleeding complications.

Common adverse effects that follow TRUS biopsy include rectal bleeding, gross hematuria, and hematospermia, all of which are usually self-limited. Fever, urinary infection and retention occur in less than 5% of patients.

questions.text: Which of the following features would be considered as a contraindication for endoscopic mucosal resection in a patient with early gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulcerated gastric cancer as ulceration indicates advanced disease. 

Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer:

  1. Tumors smaller than 2cm
  2. Tumors limited to the mucosa
  3. No lymphovascular invasion
  4. No ulceration
  5. Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology.

If any of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

FDA has approved the use of Nivolumab in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs, for the initial treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic gastric cancer, GE junction cancer, and esophageal adenocarcinoma. This is the first FDA- approved immunotherapy for the first-line treatment of gastric cancer.

questions.text: You have started a continous infusion of drug Y in a patient at a rate of 100 mg/hr. Drug Y has a Vd of 200 liters and a clearance of 6L/hr. What will be the drug concentration at a steady state?
questions.solution:
Steady state concentration (Css) for this drug is 16.66 mg/L.

Steady state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion / clearance.

Rate of infusion = 100 mg/h

Clearance = 6L/h

Css = (100 mg/hr) / (6L/hr) = 16.66 mg/L

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a smoker is found to have elevated transaminases. Neurological examination is normal and his liver biopsy shows inclusions that are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant, as shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely to be associated with the underlying condition?

choices.text: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination
Beading of intra and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP
Emphysematous changes of lung bases on CT thorax

questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. Bullous changes of lung bases on CT thorax indicative of pulmonary emphysema is associated with this condition. 

α1-antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin into the serum. It is caused by a mutation in the SERPINA1 gene located in the long arm of chromosome 14. This genetic defect alters the configuration of the α1-antitrypsin molecule and prevents its release from hepatocytes. As a result, serum levels of α1-antitrypsin are decreased, leading to low alveolar concentrations, where the α1-antitrypsin molecule normally would provide protection against proteases such as neutrophil elastase. The resulting protease excess in alveoli destroys alveolar walls and causes emphysema.

Periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes are seen in the biopsy in these patients.

Distinguishing features from other conditions affecting the liver are - 

  α1-antitrypsin deficiency Wilson's disease Hemochromatosis
Pathogenesis Deficiency of alpha-1 AT on chromosome 14 ATP7B gene mutation on chromosome 13 HFE gene mutation on chromosome 6p
Clinically affected organs Pan-acinar emphysema, liver Liver, brain, Keyer-Fleischer ring Skin, diabetes, micronodular cirrhosis of liver, arthritis, hypogonadism
Investigations   Decreased ceruloplasmin, increased copper excretion  Increased iron, ferritin, and TIBC
Liver biopsy PAS-positive and diastase resistant globuless Steatosis, hepatitis, positive with rhodamine, orcein Hemosiderin deposition, Prussian blue stain positive

Other options - 

Option A: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination suggests Wilson's disease. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to the mutation in the ATP7B gene. This leads to ATP7B protein deficiency causing impaired excretion of biliary copper. This results in copper toxicity primarily involving the liver and brain. Mallory-Denk bodies (also called alcoholic hyaline  bodies) are seen here which are clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion bodies in ballooned liver cells. These are predominantly composed of keratin intermediate filaments (keratin 8 and 18).

 

Option B: Beading of intra and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP suggest primary sclerosing cholangitis. It is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments, typically showing onion-skin fibrosis surrounding the bile duct. 

 

Option D: Myocardial iron deposition on MRI is seen in hemochromatosis and the histopathology section of the liver shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm that stain positive with Prussian blue stain.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings would typically be seen in a patient with an injury to the membranous urethra?
questions.solution:
High-riding prostate is the typical finding seen in the membranous urethral injury. 

Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture, and this fracture is usually seen in road traffic accidents. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and on digital rectal examination, there will be a high riding prostate. Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum, and the pubic area is commonly associated.

Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Butterfly distribution of hematoma in the perineum is seen in bulbar urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It is seen commonly in cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents. 

Option C: Cobb's collar refers to the congenital narrowing of the bulbar urethra seen in patients with posterior urethral valve.

Option D: Scrotal extravasation of urine is typically seen in patients with bulbar urethral injury. The extravasated urine is confined in front of the mid-perineal point by the Colles’ fascia attaching to the triangular ligament and by the Scarpa’s fascia attaching just below the inguinal ligament. The external spermatic fascia stops it from getting into the inguinal canals. So, the extravasated urine collects in the scrotum and penis and beneath the deep layer of superficial fascia in the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either complete or incomplete. 

  • A complete HH is characterised by loss of entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes.
  • An incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Incomplete HH is further classified as congruous or incongruous, depending on whether the extent of partial loss of visual field in both the eyes is same or different, respectively.

Lesions involving occipital lobe usually shows macular sparing because macular representation is seperate and quite large as compared to peripheral vision. Moreover, macular area in occipital lobe is supplied both by posterior and middle cerebral artery. In case of vascular lesions (eg stroke) affecting occipital lobe, it is less likely to involve both these arteries.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: All of the following would be consistent with a diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder except:

choices.text: Failure to conform to social norms

questions.solution:
The individual should be at least 18 years old for diagnosing this disorder, though behavioral changes may start as early as 15 years old.

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for antisocial personality disorder:

  • The individual is at least 18 years of age.
  • There is evidence of conduct disorder with onset before 15 years of age.
  • Three or more of the following, occurring since age 15 years:
    • Failure to conform to social norms
    • Deceitfulness, like repeated lying
    • Impulsivity or failure to plan ahead
    • Irritability and aggressiveness
    • Reckless disregard for the safety of self or others
    • Consistent irresponsibility
    • Lack of remorse
  • The occurrence of antisocial behavior is not exclusively during schizophrenia or bipolar disorder.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with complaints of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. She was hospitalized for pneumonia and was on antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. Sigmoidoscopy revealed multiple yellowish plaques from the rectum to the sigmoid colon; her CECT image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the CT image showing the accordion sign, is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis.

The accordion sign or concertina sign is seen in the CT abdomen of patients with pseudomembranous colitis. It refers to the thickened edematous bowel appearing similar to the folds of an accordion. This appearance is caused by the stretching of the hyperemic, enhancing mucosa over the thickened submucosal folds. This is also seen when the contrast agent is trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon.

The accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in the following conditions:

  • Ischemic colitis
  • AIDS-related colitis
  • Severe edema from cirrhosis

Pseudomembranous colitis: It is usually caused by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile. It is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes C. difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of this condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). 

PMC is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers. can persist on surfaces for months. Risk factors include poor hand hygiene, old age, and gastrointestinal surgery.

The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially, which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and the detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 

Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

Other options:

Option B: In Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction, a massively dilated colon without any mechanical obstruction is seen. It is a functional disorder, usually associated with narcotics, bed rest, and comorbidities.

Option C: Toxic megacolon appears as a massively dilated colon with additional loss of haustral markings with pseudopolyps on CT.

Option D: Sigmoid volvulus appears as a coffee-bean or bent inner tube sign on plain x-ray and shows the pathognomonic bird's beak sign on gastrografin enema.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Globular (G) actin is a part of microfilaments and is not an intermediate filament.

There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

1. Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

2. Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibres are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not possess the quality of active reorganization like actin and microtubules. They are responsible for cellular tensile strength, which allows the cells to bear mechanical stress.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. Mutations in lamin proteins are associated with certain disorders such as familial partial lipodystrophy type 2, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, and familial dilated cardiomyopathy.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium).
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are found in neuronal axons, imparting strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Present in glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins

These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins.

There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (found in epithelial cells) and trichocytic keratins (found in hair-keratin).

3. Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin. The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing centre (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is evident from the histological section of the skin shown below?
questions.solution:
The above histological image shows the presence of nucleated cells in the stratum corneum, which indicates parakeratosis. Note that normally, the cells of stratum corneum are devoid of nucleus.

  • Parakeratosis is defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within the horny cell layer or stratum corneum.
  • It represents a disorder of keratinization, and is usually associated with an absence or reduction in thickness of the granular cell layer.
  • The histological feature of parakeratosis is commonly seen in many different forms of inflammatory dermatosis, and is closely associated either with increased epidermal cell turnover or with inflammatory changes in the epidermis itself.

Parakeratosis is commonly seen in

  • Psoriasis
  • Subacute eczematous reactions
  • Pityriasis lichenoides
  • Actinic keratoses
  • Bowen disease

questions.text: The differential diagnosis of a child with biphasic stridor should include all except:
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia causes inspiratory stridor. Hence, it is not considered as part of the differential diagnosis for biphasic stridor.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 58-year-old post-menopausal lady comes to you with a DEXA report showing a T-score of -2.8 SD. Which of the following braces can be used to prevent pathological vertebral fractures in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with a T score of - 2.8SD is suggestive of Osteoporosis. 2 braces that can be used in the prophylactic bracing of the spine for the prevention of pathological vertebral fractures are the Anterior spinal hyperextension braces (ASHE) brace and the Taylor brace.

Taylor brace - It is indicated for stabilization of the spine in dorsolumbar spinal injury. It is designed to control the upper and lower regions of the spinal column and support the spine while standing, sitting, and walking after spinal surgery.


ASHE brace - ASHE brace is an anterior spinal hyperextension brace used in dorsolumbar spinal injury. A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending.


Scoliosis can also be managed with the Boston brace which is a type of thoracic-lumbar-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 

The image given below shows the Boston brace:

 

Milwaukee brace - Milwaukee brace can be used for the management of Scoliosis and kyphosis. Also known as cervico-thoraco-lumbosacral orthosis or CTLSO, it is a back brace used in the treatment of spinal curvatures (such as scoliosis or kyphosis) in children. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

The image shown below is the Milwaukee brace.


SOMI Brace - The Sterno-occipital mandibular immobilization (SOMI) brace is used for cervical spine injury. It may also be used as a recovery aid following cervical spine surgery.

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipochrome (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. Lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin; it is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal aging patients.

Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes
  • Prominent in the liver, brain, and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.


Option C: Mallory bodies are seen in Indian childhood cirrhosis and Wilson’s disease.


Option D: Cholesterol deposits are seen in atherosclerosis and xanthomas.

questions.text: A young man comes to you with complaints of upper abdominal pain, feeling of indigestion and bloating sensation. Assessing the symptoms you plan to start him on omeprazole. How will you prescribe the medication to him?

The drugs are prescribed in generic names legibly and preferably in capital letters. questions.text: During dissection, the professor points to a structure in the popliteal fossa marked with the red arrow shown in the image below. He further mentions that damage to this structure would cause a high-stepping gait and an inability to dorsiflex the ankle. The structure marked is ______.
questions.solution:
The damaged structure is most likely a common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa till the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (as shown in the image below)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

 

 

Other options:

Option B: Sural nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C: Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D: Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

questions.text: All of the following findings would satisfy the Amsel criteria except:
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs are not included in Amsel’s criteria. Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the alteration of normal vaginal flora. It is not an inflammation. Hence, only a few polymorphs are seen on saline microscopy.

Amsel’s criteria are used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  1. A homogenous vaginal discharge
  2. A vaginal pH of > 4.5
  3. An amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test)
  4. Presence of clue cells

If three out of the above-mentioned four criteria are positive, then a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made.

questions.text: Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for?
questions.solution:
Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for early pregnancy testing.

Nishchay is a home-based Pregnancy Test Kit (PTK) that was launched under NRHM across the country and was later anchored with the Family Planning Division. The pregnancy test kits are being made available at the sub-center level and are also distributed to ASHA.

These pregnancy test kits are supplied free of cost and are home-based and easy to use. It facilitates early detection and also decision-making for the outcomes of pregnancy. Helping to detect pregnancy as early as one week after the missed period, provides an early opportunity for medical termination of pregnancy, thus saving lives lost to unsafe abortions.

Note: NIKSHAY is an online tool launched by the government for RNTCP to monitor tuberculosis in the country.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female patient was found to have a pedunculated fibroid of 3x3 cm in size during a routine annual health check-up. She has had no history of menstrual disturbances, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, or pressure symptoms. What is the best way to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Pedunculated fibroids need to be excised, even if the patient is asymptomatic, as they can undergo torsion at any time. The best way to manage this patient is by laparoscopic myomectomy.

Management of uterine leiomyomas: 

In asymptomatic patients - Observation with regular follow-up is done regardless of the size of the fibroid. However, surgery is indicated in cases of -

  • Cornual fibroid causing infertility
  • Pedunculated fibroid
  • Pregnancy with torsion of a pedunculated fibroid

In symptomatic patients -

Medical management -

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid– Mifepristone, danazol, low-dose oral contraceptives, SPRMs (selective progesterone-receptor modulators), GnRH analogs, letrozole, tranexamic acid

Radiological interventions -

  • Uterine Artery Embolisation (UAE)
  • Magnetic Resonance- guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS)

Surgical methods -

  • Myomectomy - laparoscopic/ abdominal
  • Laparoscopic myolysis
  • Hysterectomy - vaginal/ abdominal/ laparoscopic - total/subtotal
  • Endometrial ablation
  • Hysteroscopic polypectomy

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with purplish, itchy, flat-topped lesions on his shins for the past 3 months. On physical examination, a fine reticular lacy pattern was noticed on the oral mucosa as shown in the below image.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the lesions along with Wickham's striae shown in the image are diagnostic of Lichen planus.

Lichen planus is a type of lichenoid disorder affecting the papillary dermis. It is a T-cell mediated autoimmune disease against the basal keratinocytes. It is a chronic disease with a number of relapses and remissions.

Various factors can precipitate the disease like:

  • Viruses like: Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Human herpes viruses (HHV-6, HHV-8), Varicella zoster
  • HLA-A3, HLA-5 association
  • Environmental factors like:
    • Drugs like antimicrobials, antihypertensives, antimalarials, antidepressants, anticonvulsants
    • Radiotherapy
    • Anxiety, depression, stress

The most common presentation of lichen planus is a well-defined area of purple-colored, itchy, flat-topped papules. This description is known as the characteristic "6 Ps" of lichen planus: planar (flat-topped), purple, polygonal, pruritic, papules, and plaques.

White streaks forming a lacework in buccal mucosa is a characteristic feature and are known as Wickham’s striae.

 

Complications of lichen planus includes:

  • Hair: patches of cicatricial alopecia
  • Nails: linear depressions, exaggeration of the longitudinal lines, pterygium unguis - where adhesion between the epidermis of the dorsal nail fold and the nail bed causes a partial destruction of the nail

 

  • Mucous membranes: Squamous cell carcinoma may occur on the lip, buccal mucosa or gum margin

Investigations include:

  • Histology: Most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis.Basal epidermal cell degeneration/destruction by dermal CD8+ T lymphocytes is characteristically seen in lichen planus. Other findings are:
    • Degenerating/apoptotic basal epidermal cells are known as colloid bodies (cytoid/Civatte bodies), which may appear singly or in clumps.
    • Pigment incontinence - melanin gradually moves into the dermis as a result of keratinocyte degeneration
    • Dermal melanin is then engulfed by the macrophages forming melanophages (melanin-containing macrophages).
    • The degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max-Joseph spaces.
    • The rete ridges are pointed at their lower end giving them a saw-toothed appearance.
    • Band-like lymphocytic infiltrate is present at the dermoepidermal junction. 
    • Hyperkeratosis and hypergranulosis

 

  • Dermascopy: Wickham’s striae can be visualized as a network of whitish striae with red globules at the periphery
  • Direct immunofluorescence: Globular deposits of IgM, IgG and IgA, indicating apoptotic keratinocytes, around the dermo epidermal junction and lower epidermis. Fibrin deposition is seen at the dermoepidermal junction.

The main treatment in the case of persistent lichen planus is steroids.

  • The first line of therapy is always very potent topical steroids to be used until remission.
  • Second-line treatment is initiated if no evolution is seen after 6 weeks. It consists of systemic steroids, retinoids, and PUVA/UVB.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman develops a fever, headache,  agitation, and focal seizures. Her T2-weighted MR shows a high signal intensity in the temporal lobe, as shown below, prompting suspicion of Herpes Simplex encephalitis. What is the most sensitive investigation to diagnose this condition?

choices.text: Brain biopsy to show ballooned cells
CSF examination to analyse cell counts

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Herpes simplex encephalitis. The clinical hallmark of HSV encephalitis is the acute onset of fever and focal neurologic symptoms and signs, especially in the temporal lobe. The most sensitive investigation for this is HSV DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR.

HSV causes hemorrhagic necrosis of the inferomedial temporal and frontal lobe. 

Both HSV 1 and HSV 2 cause Herpes simplex encephalitis. Patients present with fever, headache, seizures, personality, and behavioral changes.

PCR amplification of viral DNA from the cerebrospinal fluid is the most sensitive means of detection and is recommended for the diagnosis of herpes meningitis or encephalitis.

CSF shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, moderately elevated protein levels, and normal glucose concentration.

EEG shows periodic lateralized spike-wave discharges.

 The drug of choice for HSV encephalitis is acyclovir.

 This coronal T2-weighted MR image shows high signal in the temporal lobes including hippocampal formations and parahippogampal gyrae, insulae, and right inferior frontal gyrus.

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for unexplained cough and shortness of breath. Investigations revealed elevated serum calcium and a chest X-ray showed hilar lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy was taken to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the histopathological examination?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoidosis, in which the histopathological examination of lesions does not show Masson bodies. Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: 

  • Schaumann bodies- inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies- stellate inclusions in the giant cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. She has not conceived despite having unprotected intercourse for the past 2 years. Per vaginal examination reveals tenderness in the lateral fornices. On bimanual examination, a normal-sized nulligravid uterus is felt. A speculum examination reveals bluish-puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s painful menses (dysmenorrhea), pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), lateral fornicial tenderness, bluish spots in the posterior fornix, and infertility suggest endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue at a site outside the uterine cavity. It is found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Endometriosis can present as blue or red powdered burned lesions on the cervix or posterior vaginal fornix, scarring around the tissue (puckered look). Other features include chocolate cysts causing left/right lower quadrant pain, pain during defecation, chronic pelvic pain and infertility, right lower quadrant pain, and cyclical hemoptysis.

Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. 'Powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis, as well as yellow-brown peritoneal fluid, can be seen on laparoscopy.

For minimal disease medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormonal treatment would delay pregnancy. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser and resection of endometrioma can be done. Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) to control pain .Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Option A- Chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) closely mimics endometriosis in its symptoms and signs. Both conditions produce pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and sterility. The uterus is retroverted and fixed. But in chronic PID, thickened and slightly tender fornices or a tubo-ovarian mass is noted and speculum finding as seen in the patient described above is not seen in chronic PID.

Option B - Rectocele is a form of genital prolapse seen frequently in menopausal women, especially those with a history of pelvic floor injury or multiparity. Patients present with varying degrees of prolapsed mass per rectum that needs splinting for a satisfactory bowel movement. 

 Option C - Adenomyosis, a condition seen frequently in elderly women (Aged> 40 years), is characterized by endometrial islands in the wall of the uterus, leading to a symmetrically enlarged uterus (not more than 14 weeks size). Usual presenting features include menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea. Per vaginal exam findings are normal.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman's body was retrieved from a manhole. You are suspecting antemortem drowning. Which of the following signs will most likely support your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm is an important sign of antemortem drowning. It manifests as closed hands with firmly grasped weed, grass, sticks, etc. floating in the water. When present, it is an important sign suggesting that the victim struggled for existence while in water.

questions.text: In ECG tracings,  sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are typically seen in

choices.text: Recording done with paper speed of 12.5 mm/s
Recording done with paper speed of 50 mm/s

questions.solution:
Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in a patient that is not relaxed. 

Though the ECG recorders are configured to pick up the electrical frequency generated by the heart better, they also detect the contractions of skeletal muscles. So, unless the patient is relaxed and lying down comfortably, the tracing may show some skeletal muscle activity.

Ex:- 

A patient that is shivering due to cold, or one that has involuntary movements due to conditions like Parkinson's, etc would cause spikes in the baseline of the ECG.

In the case of shivering, the spikes would be more exaggerated and synchronized than that seen in a patient that is not adequately relaxed, because of the skeletal muscle groups contracting together in case of shivering.

Other options:

  • Patients with hypothyroidism would show bradycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and widespread T-wave inversions.
  • The recording is normally done with a paper speed of 25 mm/s.
    • Recording at 12.5 mm/s, which is slower than normal, would cause QRS complex that are close together (creating the false impression of a rapid heart rate) and P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves that are narrow and spiky
    • Recording at 50 mm/s, which is faster than normal, would produce longer intervals between QRS complexes (creating the false impression of a slow heart rate), widened QRS complexes, and an apparently long QT interval.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with abdominal pain, peripheral edema, and ascites. History revealed a loss of appetite, weight loss, and diarrhea. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of gastrin. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed the following appearance involving the fundus and body of the stomach, sparing the antrum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are diagnostic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease, also called hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy is a disorder of the stomach characterized by enlarged rugae (gastric folds). It is caused due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, which is an EGF receptor (EGFR) ligand, and hyperactivation of the epidermal growth factor receptor on gastric epithelial cells.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

The condition is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds as shown below. The antrum is usually spared. 

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option a: Infiltrative type of gastric adenocarcinoma is characterized by a thickened gastric wall and partial loss of rugal folds. These changes impart a leather bottle appearance, termed linitis plastica.

Option b: Zollinger–ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor. The tumors are found in the small intestine or pancreas. increased gastrin secretion causes, changes in gastric wall, characterized by an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Opition d: Whipple disease is an intestinal disease characterized by the triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. The disease is caused due to accumulation of bacteria-laden macrophages within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes leading to lymphatic obstruction. Impaired lymphatic drainage causes malabsorption.

questions.text: A 40-year old man presented with multiple episodes of haematuria. He was found to have high blood pressure, reduced GFR and non-nephrotic proteinuria. A renal biopsy taken shows the following findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Almost all the glomeruli are affected
Self-limiting condition, settles over the next few years
Damage to the podocytes is the ultrastructural hallmark

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the histology image showing focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall along with lipid droplets and foam cells in the sclerosed area, is suggestive of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Damage to the podocytes is the ultrastructural hallmark of this condition.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is also a podocytopathy, characterised by the degeneration and focal disruption of podocytes as well as effacement of foot processes. However, it is different from minimal change disease in the following aspects:

  • Higher incidence of hematuria
  • Reduced GFR and hypertension
  • More non- selective proteinuria
  • Poor response to corticosteroid therapy
  • Progression to chronic kidney disease, mostly resulting in end-stage kidney disease

FSGS is characterized by sclerosis of a portion (segmental) of the capillary tuft in a minority of the glomeruli (focal). It presents as an acute onset nephrotic syndrome or non-nephrotic proteinuria. Hypertension, microscopic hematuria and azotemia are commonly seen. There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant - poor prognosis
  • Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified variant - most common

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is associated with the loss of renal mass, following which adaptive changes like hypertrophy, glomerular capillary hypertension as well as systemic hypertension occur in the glomeruli. This causes epithelial and endothelial injury to podocytes resulting in proteinuria. There is mesangial cell proliferation and extracellular matrix production in response to these changes. Together with intraglomerular coagulation, there is resultant glomerulosclerosis. Thus, this will in turn cause a further loss of functioning nephrons and a vicious circle of progressive glomerulosclerosis.

Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.

Image below shows histopathological image of FSGS.

FSGS can be classified as:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis as seen in IgA nephropathy
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy

Idiopathic FSGS is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children as well as adults. 

Children are found to have a better prognosis. Progression to renal failure is variable. Usually, FSGS has a poor response to corticosteroids.  Degree of proteinuria, the degree of renal insufficiency at diagnosis and histologic subtype determines the prognosis.  

HIV-associated nephropathy is a severe form of the collapsing variant of FSGS, characterised by:

  • Focal cystic dilation of tubule segments filled with proteinaceous material, inflammation and fibrosis

  • Presence of tubuloreticular inclusions within endothelial cells, detected by electron microscopy. Such inclusions are not usually present in idiopathic FSGS and therefore may have diagnostic value in a biopsy specimen.

The image below shows the collapsing variant of FSGS.

questions.text: A young girl of class 4 complains of a burning sensation in the eye. Clinical examination of eyes reveals the finding shown below. What could be the mechanism for the development of such lesions?

choices.text: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is showing Bitot spots, which occur due to keratinization of the conjunctival epithelium. Bitot spots are triangular, frequently bilateral, and present on the bulbar conjunctiva.

Normally, bulbar conjunctiva is a stratified, columnar, non-keratinized epithelium. In vitamin A deficiency, there is squamous metaplasia of the conjunctival epithelium and tangles of keratin admixed with gas-forming bacteria producing a dry, scaly patch with a foamy appearance called Bitot spots.

Option A: Deposition of calcium in the conjunctiva is termed conjunctival concretions, which usually occurs over the palpebral conjunctiva, in chronic inflammatory conditions of the eye.

Option B: Scarring of the conjunctiva is seen in chlamydial infection of the eye.

Option C: Excessive growth of conjunctival tissue is seen in the pterygium of the eye.

questions.text: You are interpreting data collected from a city to write a research paper on the extent of pollution in it. You come across the soiling index. What is it an indicator of?
questions.solution:
The soiling index or smoke index is an indicator of air pollution.

The soiling index is a measure of the total suspended particulate matter in air. A known air volume is filtered through a white filter paper, and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter. It is expressed as micrograms/ cubic meters of air over a certain period. The best indicators of air pollution include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. 

Currently, the Air Quality Index (AQI) is the most commonly used tool for the air quality status and severity of pollution. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration  to calculate the AQI -

  • PM10 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (carbon monoxide)
  • O3 (ozone)
  • NH3 (ammonia)
  • Pb (lead)

The National AQI categories and the range are as follows :

AQI Category AQI Range
Good 0 - 50
Satisfactory 51 - 100
Moderate 101 - 200
Poor 201 - 300
Very poor 301 - 400
Severe 401 - 500

 

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter

  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. ECG strip obtained is shown in the image below. His BP is 120/76 mm Hg. Vagal maneuvers were tried but failed. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG strip is suggestive of the AV nodal reentry (AVNRT) variant of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. 

PSVT spans a variety of tachycardia that differ based on the pathway of impulse conduction. They include AV node reentry, AV reentry via an accessory pathway, and atrial tachycardia. AVNRT is the most commonly seen pattern of PSVT in healthy adults, especially in women. This form of PSVT is due to the re-entry of the electrical impulse from the AV node to the right atrium via either of the 2 pathways (superior fast pathway and inferior slow pathway).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (green arrows) at 150 bpm - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm. 
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 
 
 
Treatment - Since AVNRT depends on the functionality of the AV node, administering adenosine terminates most cases of tachycardia. This drug transiently blocks AV conduction by activating acetylcholine-sensitive K+ current in the atria, SAN, and AV nodes. These changes lead to a short action potential duration, hyperpolarization of the nodal tissues, and slowing of automaticity.
Intravenous verapamil or diltiazem can be used alternatively in patients who cannot tolerate adenosine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman came with complaints of massive painless vaginal bleeding. She also reported amenorrhea for 2 months. The histopathological examination of the endometrium showed a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of painless vaginal bleeding preceded by amenorrhea with histopathological examination of the endometrium revealing a characteristic Swiss cheese pattern is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica.

Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory DUB, seen in women aged 40 to 45 years. The typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are:

  • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm
  • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as Swiss cheese pattern
  • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e. absence of corkscrew glands 
  • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity
  • Corpus luteum is absent
  • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst

Other options

Option A: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, menorrhagia, and infertility.

Option C: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow are present. 

Option D: Endometrial carcinoma usually presents as postmenopausal bleeding. There may be a history of PCOS or HRT indicating chronic estrogen exposure. There will be no Swiss cheese appearance on histopathological examination.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of warty cutaneous growth on the foot of the farmer and microscopic finding of sclerotic bodies suggests a diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. Clinical features include warty, cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of a cauliflower, usually confined to feet and lower legs. 

Diagnosis is a histopathological examination of the lesions which show the presence of fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies as shown below.

Treatment:- Relapse is very common in this disease. Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. If surgery is not feasible or for larger lesions chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole is efficacious.

Other options:

Option A -  In sporotrichosis patients present with nodulo-ulcerative lesions which spread proximally along the lymphatics. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. 

Option B - Mycetoma is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes). It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

The image below shows a mycetoma of the foot:

Option D - Phaeohyphomycosis: It is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions may be plaques that are verrucous, hyperkeratotic or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: Which of the following findings will be found in neuroimaging of a patient with Pick's disease?

choices.text: Atrophy of frontal and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
Atrophy of frontal and temporal lobes will be found in neuroimaging of a patient with Pick's disease

History of personality changes, compulsivity followed by issues of memory, later on, are seen in patients with frontotemporal dementias(FTD), including Pick’s disease. In the behavioral variant (bvFTD), the most common FTD syndrome, social and emotional systems dysfunction manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, and overeating, often but not always accompanied by deficits in executive control. When bvFTD is accompanied by motor neuron disease (MND), the term FTD-MND is applied.

Other Options:

Option A: Dilated ventricles are seen in Normal-pressure hydrocephalus. The patient presents with Ataxia, urinary incontinence, and dementia.

Option C: Atrophy of the medial temporal lobe is seen in Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer’s patients present with short-term memory loss and develop personality changes later on.

Option D: Cortical microinfarcts are seen in Vascular dementia, which presents as step ladder decline of cognitive and behavioral function depending on the region involved.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains of dull pain in the lower back for 8 months. He also complains of early morning stiffness which improves only on exercising. Ankylosing spondylitis is suspected. Which of the following is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of this disease, as per the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis international Society (ASAS) categorization criteria?

choices.text: Limited motion of the lumbar spine
X-ray of spine showing a bamboo appearance

questions.solution:
Sacroiliitis is an essential criterion for the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis. The clinical presentation of a young male with backache, morning stiffness, redness of the eye, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker (About 85 percent).

ASAS Categorization Criteria for spondyloarthritis in patients under 45 years of age with lower back pain of 3 months duration

Criteria comprise 2 sections: one ‘‘radiological section’’ and one ‘‘clinical section’’.

  • To qualify for the radiological section a sacroiliitis on simple radiography or MRI and at least one of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis needs to be confirmed.
  • To qualify for the clinical section the patient needs to have a positive HLA B27 and at least two of the characteristic traits of spondyloarthritis without radiologic sacroiliitis being mandatory

Radiological diagnosis of sacroiliitis 
      - Active (acute) inflammation in the MRI is highly suggestive of sacroiliitis due to spondyloarthritis 
      - Radiological sacroiliitis is defined according to the New York criteria (grade >2 bilateral or grade 3 - 4 unilateral)

Features of spondyloarthritis

  • Low inflammatory pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis
  • Uveítis
  • Dactylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn/colitis
  • Good response to NSAID
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA B27
  • High CRP levels

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Cardinal sign/earliest sign– erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints
    • Later- peri-articular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body (‘squaring’)
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine.
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints.

Extra-articular involvements are seen as the disease progresses.

  • Ocular - The most common extra-articular manifestation is anterior uveitis, typically unilateral, and recurs often
  • Pulmonary - Fibrosis of the upper lobe of the lungs
  • Cardiac - Acute aortic insufficiency, heart blocks
  • Gastrointestinal - inflammation of the ileum or colon
  • Dermatological - Psoriasis
  • Renal - Secondary IgA nephropathy
  • Peripheral joint involvement - shoulder and hips (presence indicates poor prognosis)

Complications that are likely to be seen due to this disease are -

  • Most common serious complication is spinal fracture. Lower cervical spine is the most common area for fracture
  • Loss of lumbar curvature (lumbar lordosis) causing limitation of movements in all directions
  • Gluteal muscle atrophy
  • Forward bending (kyphosis) of the thoracic spine leading to reduced chest movements and shallow breathing

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient, with a history of upper respiratory tract infection, presents with rapidly progressing, symmetric, ascending paralysis since 7 days. The knee jerk reflex is absent bilaterally. Investigations show elevated CSF protein levels. Which of the following is affected by this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness, following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is an immune-mediated disease, where autoimmune cells attack the myelin proteins of the peripheral nervous system. 

GBS is caused by an immune response and/or antibodies produced against external antigens (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and human herpesvirus [HHV]) introduced by infections  or by vaccines such as influenza vaccine. These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue—a phenomenon called molecular mimicry.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

Glia (Greek: glue) are cells that help in communication within the CNS. They are classified into 2 types according to their sizes—microglia and macroglia. Macroglia are of 3 types—astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation around the axons of the peripheral nerves and nerves in the brain and spinal cord respectively. Myelin protein zero (P0) and hydrophobic protein PMP22 are components of the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in different conditions: 

  • Multiple sclerosis - Patchy destruction of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome - Autoimmune destruction of myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22)
  • Charcot-Marrie-Tooth disease - Mutations in the myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22) causing disruption of myelin and axonal degeneration.

questions.text: Urinalysis reveals urine that turns black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in the patient?
questions.solution:
Urine that turns black on exposure to air is suggestive of alkaptonuria. It occurs due to a defect in the homogentisate oxidase enzyme, that oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

In this disorder, the enzyme defect leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. The excreted homogentisate gets oxidized when exposed to the air and causes the urine to turn black.

The excessive homogentisate may also get oxidized to benzoquinone acetate, which binds to connective tissue. This leads to arthritis and pigmentation of the connective tissue, a condition called ochronosis. These patients are at higher risk of renal stones (and of prostate stones for males), usually in the later stages of the disease.

questions.text: While working out at the gymnasium, you witness a weightlifter collapse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide basic life support to this victim?

choices.text: Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, check for pulse, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, call the emergency response team,  assess responsiveness, check for pulse, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation(CPR)
Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse , commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, check for pulse,  assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)

questions.solution:
Basic life support should be provided in the following sequence for a witnessed collapse: verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse, and then commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

First, assess scene safety to ensure the environment is safe for the rescuers and the victim.

The next step is to check for responsiveness. If unresponsive, activate the emergency response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED) before starting CPR if you are alone. Otherwise, send someone to activate the response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED).

Check the patient for a carotid pulse for 5-10 seconds. If the patient has a pulse but no normal breathing or only gasping, provide 1 breath every 6 seconds or 10-12 rescue breaths /minute and recheck pulse every 2 minutes.

If the patient does not have a pulse and is not breathing, proceed to provide high-quality CPR.

Continuous chest compressions should be given on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum by pushing hard and fast at the rate of 100-120/minute, at a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5-6 cm) allowing complete chest recoil after every compression. Rescue breaths are given every 6 seconds or 10-12 breaths/minute.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty should be at the compression rate is 100 - 120/min  (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec), depth of 2 inches by pressing hard and fast. Allow for full chest recoil after every compression. Minimize interruptions in chest compression to less than 10 seconds.

Analyze if it is a shockable rhythm when the AED arrives. If it is shockable, then give one shock and proceed with CPR. If it is a non-shockable rhythm then continue CPR immediately.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Neurocutaneous syndomes

Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: VHL gene, tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Conditions associated with it include:
    • Renal cell carcinoma
    • Hemangioblastomas
    • Pheochromocytomas
    • Angiomatosis
    • Cysts in the pancreas, liver, and kidneys

Neurofibromatosis type 1: 

  • Also known as Von Recklinghausen Disease
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF1 gene on chromosome 17, codes for the Neurofibromin protein
  • Features of NF 1:  “CAFE SPOTS”
    • Café-au-lait spots (multiple, >6, >5 mm in children or >15 mm in adults)
    • Axillary or inguinal freckling
    • Family history (autosomal dominant inheritance)
    • Eye findings (Lisch nodules on the iris)
    • Skin neurofibromas (benign tumors)
    • Plexiform neurofibromas (larger, deeper tumors)
    • Optic pathway gliomas (tumors of the optic nerve)
    • Tibial dysplasia (bone abnormalities, e.g., bowing of the tibia)
    • Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis)

Neurofibromatosis type 2:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that codes for the Merlin protein
  • Features: "MISME"
    • Multiple schwannomas (bilateral vestibular schwannomas are hallmark)
    • Intracranial meningiomas
    • Spinal tumors (ependymomas, schwannomas)
    • Meningiomas (intracranial or spinal)
    • Ependymomas (spinal cord tumors)

Tuberous sclerosis: 

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Mutation in the TSC 1 gene on chromosome 9 and TSC 2 on chromosome 16
  • Features: “HAMARTOMAS”
    • Hamartomas in skin and CNS
    • Ash-leaf spots (Hypopigmented macules)
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Rhabdomyomas of the heart
    • Tuberous sclerosis
    • Autosomal dOMinant
    • Angiomyolipomas
    • Seizures and shagreen patches
    • Also associated with intellectual disability

Sturge Weber Syndrome

  • Also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis
  • Somatic mosaicism due to mutation in GNAQ gene
  • Features: “STURGE - I”
    • Portwine Stain (Nevus flammeus)
    • Tram track calcifications (leptomeningeal angioma)
    • Unilateral weakness
    • Retinal detachment and atrophy
    • Glaucoma

    • Intellectual disability

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with regurgitation of food and exacerbated nocturnal cough for a week. He also notices gurgling sounds while swallowing.  On barium fluoroscopic examination, the given finding is seen. Surgical correction of the given defect is by -
questions.solution:
The given image is a contrast radiography imaging of the upper oesophagus using barium swallow in a patient with Zenker's diverticulum. It should be managed using the Dohlman's procedure

Zenker's diverticulum:

Zenker diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus.

Surgical anatomy:

  • The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fibres and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.
  • This is the site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall and therefore is the potential site for the development of the diverticula (Zenker's diverticula).
  • Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the longitudinal muscle of the oesophagus while the circular muscle forms the wall. 

Cause:

Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Clinical presentation: The entrapment of liquid and/or food within the diverticulum may result in:

  • Globus sensation
  • Dysphagia
  • Halitosis
  • Regurgitation
  • Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis is by Barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy

The most serious complication from an untreated Zenker's diverticulum is aspiration pneumonia or lung abscess.

Treatment:

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The endoscopic treatment of Zenker's diverticulum is also called the Dohlman technique. It is a transoral endoscopic approach in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical oesophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Lesions less than 2 cm can be managed with myotomy. Sac more than 5 cm can be excised.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A patient who had been prescribed isoniazid reports to the hospital with symptoms of photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and forgetfulness. Casal's necklace was observed on examination. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is unlikely to present with a similar clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B5 deficiency is not associated with pellagra.

The triad of dermatitis, diarrhoea and dementia is characteristic of pellagra. It occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin B3 (niacin). Pellagra-like symptoms are also known to be caused by the deficiency of tryptophan, and micronutrients required for conversion of tryptophan to niacin (iron, riboflavin (vitamin B2), pyridoxine (vitamin B6)). It can also be seen in alcoholics. The antitubercular drug isoniazid is a structural analogue of niacin and can precipitate pellagra.

Symptoms of pellagra -

  • Bright red glossitis followed by characteristic scaling and pigmentation of the skin that is exposed to the sun
  • Diarrhoea
  • Depression
  • Dementia
  • Seizures

Pellagra can be fatal if not treated promptly.

The image below shows casal's necklace, a ring-like rash seen around the neck, caused due to the deficiency of niacin.

 

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.
