questions.text: An infant was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of vomiting and abdominal distention. The parents inform that the baby passes stools that look like currant jelly. On ultrasonography, a target sign was observed. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Rota virus vaccine is not associated with increased risk
The most common cause is idiopathic
The most common location is ileocolic region

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of intussusception and the rotavirus vaccine is associated with an increased risk, albeit only a slightly increased risk

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. Ileoileal location is seen postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura.

90% of cases of intussusception in children are idiopathic in nature. It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with a slightly increased risk of intussusception.

Lead points are more common in children older than 2 years of age and can cause recurrent intussusception. Some recognizable lead points are as follows: enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, neurofibroma, intestinal duplication cysts, leiomyomas, hamartomas, anastomotic suture line, enterostomy tube, hemangioma, or malignant conditions such as lymphoma or Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.text: A woman presented to you with the following finding. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows uterine prolapse, for which an episiotomy is not a risk factor. Episiotomy shortens the second stage of labor and prevents the atonicity of the uterus, thus reducing the risk of prolapse.

The risk factors for uterine prolapse are:

  • Pregnancy
  • Vaginal delivery
  • Menopause
    • Aging
    • Hypoestrogenism
  • Peripheral nerve injury to the pudendal nerve
  • Premature bearing down before full dilatation of the cervix
  • Chronically increased intra-abdominal pressure
    • Chronic bronchitis
    • Constipation
    • Obesity
  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Congenital weakness of pelvic floor muscles
  • Abdominoperineal excision of rectum 
  • Surgeries such as Stamey and Pereyra operation for stress incontinence

questions.text: Which of the following components helps differentiate interstitial fluid from plasma?
questions.solution:
The lower protein levels help to differentiate interstitial fluid from plasma. 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) compartment includes interstitial fluids and plasma. The plasma and the interstitial fluid are separated only by highly permeable capillary membranes because of which the ionic composition of fluids in both these compartments are similar. The most important differentiating factor is the lower concentration of proteins in the interstitial fluid. This is due to the low capillary permeability to the proteins that are present in plasma. 

In contrast to the intracellular fluid (ICF), the ECF has an abundance of sodium, chloride, calcium and bicarbonate ions, and lesser amounts of potassium, phosphate, and magnesium ions. The image below depicts the proportion of the important anions and cations present in the intracellular and extracellular fluids.

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the primary health center for a routine medical check-up. What is the dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation to be given to her, under the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative?

choices.text: 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg folic acid bi-weekly
45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly
60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid daily

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, children between 5-9 years of age need to take 45 mg elemental iron + 400 mcg folic acid tablets once a week. These tablets are sugar-coated, and pink in color.

Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme: 

This is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

Interventions:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

Beneficiaries:

  • Children, 6-59 months of age
  • Children, 5-9 years of age
  • Adolescent girls and boys, 10-19 years of age
  • Women of reproductive age, 20-49 years of age
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating mothers, 0-6 months

Institutions through which activities are carried out:

  • Intra-Ministerial Coordination
  • National Anemia Mukt Bharat Unit
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anemia Control (NCEAR-A)
  • Convergence with other Ministries
  • Strengthening Supply Chain and Logistics
  • Anemia Mukt Bharat Dashboard and Digital Portal

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with cystic neck swelling as shown in the image. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. Which of the following malignancies may develop from this, if the swelling remains untreated?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is a thyroglossal cyst. The most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma.

Though the most common complication of thyroglossal cyst is an infection, 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant, with the most common type of cancer being papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

Management:

  • Sistrunk operation (en bloc cystectomy with excision of the central hyoid bone) is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. 
  • To minimize the recurrence of the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid is excised in addition to complete cyst excision including the entire tract.

questions.text: A woman died due to septic abortion following Clostridium welchii infection. What color is the postmortem hypostasis likely to be in this case?
questions.solution:
Postmortem hypostasis seen in cases of septic abortion due to Clostridium welchii is mostly greenish-brown in color. Septic abortion due to Clostridium perfringens also produces a hypostasis of a brownish color and, in rare cases, bronze.

The terms postmortem hypostasis, postmortem staining, postmortem lividity, livor mortis, and suggillation all refer to the purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin occurring due to the postmortem collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependant parts of the body.

Features:

  • Caused by engorged vessels showing through the skin
  • Occur on dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity
  • Margins clearly defined
  • No swelling or abrasion

Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6–12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

Timing:

  • Mottled patches - 1–3 hours following death
  • Uniform area of staining - 3–6 hours following death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis - 6–12 hours following death

Postmortem hypostasis/lividity usually develops within 4 hours of death and persists until putrefaction.

During your pediatrics rotation, you notice a child with severe acute malnutrition is being treated with fluids with composition as mentioned below. What is the rehydration fluid that is used here?

questions.solution:
The above-mentioned composition refers to the rehydration fluid: Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal).

Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium-potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

Directions to use: Give ReSoMal 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hr orally or nasogastric tube. Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hr. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink.

questions.text: Test shown in the image is useful for the detection of ________________
questions.solution:
The test shown in the photograph is rapid plasma reagin test used to detect Treponema pallidum.

RPR test is one of the nonspecific tests  commonly used to screen the population for syphilis. The RPR test measures IgM and IgG antibodies to lipoidal material released from damaged host cells as well as to lipoprotein-like material, and possibly cardiolipin released from the treponemes.

Antigen used in RPR Test:

RPR antigen contains cardiolipin, lecithin, cholesterol, 10% choline chloride, EDTA, charcoal etc in buffer. The test uses the VDRL antigen containing fine carbon particle ,which makes result more clear cut and evident to naked eye.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.

It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy , anemia
, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL

  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment

questions.text: An elderly patient who presented with chest pain is undergoing coronary angiography. When the cardiologist injected the radiocontrast dye into the patient, the patient developed profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. The reflex that is responsible for this scenario is
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for the above scenario is the Bezold Jarisch reflex. 

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

Other options

Option A- C fibre endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia and hypotension. This is called the J reflex.

Option B- Cushing reflex is the increased blood pressure and bradycardia seen in patients with raised intracranial pressure. Increased intracranial pressure compresses the cerebral blood vessels and causes hypercapnia. This stimulates the central chemoreceptors located in the ventrolateral surface of the medulla and causes increased blood pressure. This increase is proportional to the increase in the intracranial pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates baroreceptors and causes bradycardia.

Option C- Brainbridge reflex is the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins and pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant lady is set to undergo dilatation and curettage. Which of the following instruments will not be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Instrument 4 is a Rubin's insufflation cannula. It is used in hysterosalpingography, but not in dilatation and curettage.

The other instruments shown are:

  1. Sim's uterine curette
  2. Hegar's dilators
  3. Simpson's uterine sound

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: It retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.

  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30-cm-long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other. It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement.

    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of sickle cell disease presents with acute chest syndrome. Which of the following is the drug of choice to reduce such painful crises in the future?
questions.solution:
Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for reducing painful crises in sickle cell anemia.

Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent that is effective in reducing the frequency of painful episodes like dactylitis and acute chest syndrome, decreasing the rate of hospitalization, and requirement for blood transfusion. It is safe and well-tolerated in children and infants.

Option A: Hydrocodone (opioid) is used in the treatment of pain crisis in sickle cell anemia.

Option C: Corticosteroids is one of the first-line therapies for acute idiopathic thrombocytic purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding.

Option D: Ruxolitinib is the drug of choice for the treatment of polycythemia vera.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

The enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for Pompe disease is the recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is undergoing investigations for excessive and spontaneous bruising. Direct microscopy of urine revealed a peculiar finding that led the physician to suspect Fabry’s disease. What is that finding?

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of hearing voices that are asking him to end his life for the past 3 weeks. He speaks in sentences that do not make complete sense. On further probing, he reveals that recently, he had witnessed losing his friend in an accident. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of auditory hallucinations and disorganized speech for the past 3 weeks in a patient with a history of witnessing a traumatic event, a provisional diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder can be made. The presence of these symptoms for less than one month and a history of a traumatic event are the clinchers for this diagnosis. 

A brief psychotic disorder is characterized by a sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day and is followed by a complete remission within a month of the appearance of the symptoms. There may also be a precipitating stressor like a traumatic life event. It is commonly seen in women, young people, and those with existing personality disorders.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder, according to DSM-5, requires the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  1. Delusions
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

According to ICD-11, this is classified as acute and transient psychotic disorder (ATPD), and the duration of the episode does not last for more than 3 months.

The diagnosis is usually anticipatory or retrospective, after ruling out other mental health disorders and substance abuse. Relapses are seen due to a lack of adherence to medication and should be monitored on a long-term basis. Management of the episode involves hospitalization and initiation of psychotherapy along with pharmacotherapy. Second-generation antipsychotics are considered the first-line treatment option, while benzodiazepines can be used to manage the symptoms in an agitated patient.

Other options:

Option A. When a manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with the major symptoms of schizophrenia, with a minimum of 2 weeks of delusions or hallucinations without mood abnormalities, schizoaffective disorder is the appropriate diagnosis.

Option C. A diagnosis of Schizophrenia, which has a similar presentation of psychotic symptoms, requires the continuous presence of these symptoms for a period of at least 6 months.

Option D. Schizophreniform disorder differs from a brief psychotic disorder in that the symptoms have a duration of at least 1 month but less than 6 months.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion that was present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis.

Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: All of the following findings point towards the diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome except:

choices.text: Multiple peptic ulcers, with some in unusual sites
Decrease of  50 pg/ml  in serum gastrin by secretin test

questions.solution:
Rise in >200 pg/ml serum gastrin after secretin test is one of the diagnostic criteria of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. It is confirmed by gastric pH < 2.5 and serum gastrin concentration > 1000 pg/ml.  

In normal individuals, the administration of secretin causes no change or a slight decrease in the blood gastrin levels. However, in patients with ZE syndrome, the circulating gastrin levels paradoxically increase following secretin administration.

Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is a gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor that includes - 

i) Fulminating lesions in the stomach, duodenum (mostly 1st and 2nd part), or atypical sites like the pancreas. Passaro's or Gastrinoma triangle is the usual site for the occurrence of tumors. It is bounded by the lines connecting the - 

  • cystic duct
  • the junction between the second and third parts of the duodenum
  • the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

ii) Recurrent ulcers despite adequate medical or surgical management. 

iii) Non-beta islet cell tumors of the pancreas (gastrinomas) 

 Medical management with proton pump inhibitors, octreotide control acid hypersecretion for a while. Definitive management is by extensive surgical resection along with regional lymph node dissection to prevent recurrences or malignancy. Pancreatic gastrinomas are treated by enucleation of the part involved along with duodenotomy. Duodenal gastrinomas less than 5 mm are enucleated, whereas if more, full-thickness excision of the duodenal wall is carried out. 

The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors along with gastrinomas is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes of E.coli exerts virulence without producing any enterotoxin?
questions.solution:
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) exert virulence without producing any enterotoxin.

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using EAF (EPEC adherence factor) and LEE (Locus of enterocyte membrane) and causes effacement of microvilli. This leads to attachment and effacement lesions of intestinal cells. Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle forming pilus encoded by a plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

Other options: 

Option A: Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin or Shiga-like-toxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome. 

Option D: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following enterotoxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
  • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
  • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: X-Ray of a 20-year-old who came to the emergency after a fall on an outstretched hand appears as below. On examination, crepitus is absent, the forearm appears shortened and the three-point bony relation is disrupted. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in patients with this condition?
questions.solution:
The lateral X-Ray of the elbow shows the coronoid process of the ulna lying posterior to the condyles of the humerus, which along with the clinical history points to this being a case of posterior dislocation of the elbow. The most common nerve injury associated with it is the ulnar nerve injury.

The order of incidence of nerve injury in elbow dislocation is Ulnar nerve > Radial nerve > Median nerve. The ulnar nerve becomes entrapped commonly as it passes posteriorly around the medial epicondyle.

Elbow dislocation is the most common dislocation in the pediatric age group and the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults.

Posterior dislocation is the commonest type of elbow dislocation. It frequently occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hands with the elbow slightly flexed. Other dislocations are postero-medial, postero-lateral, and divergent.

Anterior dislocation occurs when the elbow is flexed and there is a direct blow on the posterior aspect of the elbow joint.

Clinical features

  • The forearm appears shortened.
  • Crepitus is absent.
  • The three-point bony relationship is disrupted.
  • Olecranon is above the intercondylar line

Elbow dislocation is an emergency and has to be reduced immediately. Closed reduction under general anaesthesia(GA) is attempted first. An above elbow POP slab is applied with 90º elbow flexion and mid-pronation for a period of 3 weeks after closed reduction under GA.

Stimson’s 2 step principles for closed reduction

  • step 1 - traction along the long axis of the humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  • step 2 - traction along the long axis of the forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position

2 techniques in closed reduction

  • Prone technique- Grab the wrist of the injured arm. Apply traction and slight supination to the forearm. Using the other hand, apply pressure to the posterior aspect of the olecranon while the arm is pronated
  • supine technique- a helper stabilizes the humerus against the stretcher with both hands. Grasp the wrist, and apply slow, steady, inline traction, keeping the elbow slightly flexed and the wrist supinated

Early complications include neurovascular injury. Vascular injuries are rare and involve the brachial artery in open fractures associated with elbow dislocation.

Late complications include myositis ossificans, recurrent dislocations, proximal radioulnar translocation, and ectopic calcifications

The terrible triad of elbow includes

  • Posterior dislocation of the elbow
  • Radial head fracture
  • Fracture coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: A patient with chronic dacryocystitis, refractory to the medical treatment, has been scheduled for dacryocystorhinostomy. Following the surgery, the sac would be draining into the _______.
questions.solution:
After dacryocystorhinostomy, the lacrimal sac drains into the middle meatus.

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) surgery involves removal of the bone adjacent to the nasolacrimal sac and suturing the lacrimal sac with the lateral nasal mucosa. This allows tears to drain directly from the sac via a new low-resistance pathway into the middle meatus. 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CONS) and Staphylococcus aureus are the organisms responsible for the majority of chronic dacrocystitis cases. Chronic dacryocystitis can be treated with amoxyclav and third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought for evaluation of repeated lung infections. The bronchial fluid samples show gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a bluish-green pigment. He also has been experiencing foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools. What is the mode of inheritance of the condition that the child is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Repeated lung infections and steatorrhea (foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools) suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a blue-green pigment indicate infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is commonly seen in this condition. 

Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7 (7q31.2). It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

  • Lungs - Abnormal CFTR leads to sticky viscous mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance leading to obstruction and recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - The viscous secretions block the pancreatic ducts impairing the flow of digestive enzymes. This leads to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing fat malabsorption and the resultant steatorrhea. 
  • Reproductive tract - More than 95% of men are infertile, with absent vas deferens. Women have tenacious cervical mucus but are not always infertile. 

The sweat chloride test is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Sweat ducts with normal CFTR reabsorb the chloride from the primary sweat secretion. Mutated CFTR reduces this uptake, increasing chloride levels in sweat. A sweat chloride level of >60 mmol/L is diagnostic.

Other pathogens commonly causing infections in cystic fibrosis include Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Burkholderia cepacia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps. On examination, she appeared confused and lab reports show serum calcium of 13 mg/dl, low phosphorous, and raised PTH. Which of the following skull x-ray would likely be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is diagnostic of primary hyperparathyroidism and the number 3 skull x-ray image depicting pepper pot appearance is typically seen in this condition. 

Hyperparathyroidism caused due to increased parathyroid hormone results in osteoclastic resorption of bone leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, and confusion. Lab values showing high calcium, low phosphorous, and raised PTH confirm the diagnosis. 

The salt and pepper appearance of the skull also known as pepper pot skull is a characteristic finding of hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occurs due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological features of hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges
  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica - also called brown tumors and Von Recklinghausen's disease. In the areas of bone resorption, the bone tissue is replaced with proliferating fibrous tissue, hemorrhage, and necrosed tissue. The hemorrhage leads to the accumulation of hemoglobin which is converted to hemosiderin. This hemosiderin gives it a brown color. The term tumor is a misnomer.
  • Rugger jersey spine refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae and mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 
  • Loss of lamina dura of teeth
  • Generalized osteopenia

Other options - 

 

Image 1 shows punched-out lesions, and it is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

 

Image 2 shows a cotton wool appearance and it is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table.
  • Diploic widening
  • Tom o' Shanter sign

 

Image 4 shows a J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note:

J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida developed fever and pruritic vesicular rashes one day after a full-term normal vaginal delivery. A diagnosis of varicella infection was made. How should the neonate be managed?

choices.text: Acyclovir therapy should be started immediately

questions.solution:
Passive immunization with Varicella-Zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) is administered to neonates whose mothers develop a varicella-zoster rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery.

If the fetus or neonate is exposed to active varicella infection just before or during delivery, they may develop a disseminated visceral and central nervous system disease, which can be fatal. Neonte is not at risk of severe neonatal chicken pox, if mother contracts infection before and after this period (i.e 5 days before and 2 days after delivery), in that case passive immunisation is not required.

VZIG may not prevent infection, but reduces the severity of neonatal infection. Monitoring of the neonate should be prolonged to 28 days, as VZIG may prolong the incubation period.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, the neonate should be treated with acyclovir. 

Primary varicella infection presents with flu-like symptoms, followed by a pruritic vesicular rash. The fetus may develop congenital varicella syndrome if infection occurs in the first half of pregnancy, the highest risk is between 13 and 20 weeks. Features of congenital varicella syndrome include:

  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

Pregnant women who are exposed to varicella and are susceptible should be given VZIG. Infected women usually require only supportive care, but those who require intravenous (IV) fluids and or develop pneumonia should be hospitalized. Intravenous acyclovir therapy is given to women requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: The arthropod shown in the image is a vector for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The arthropod shown in the image is a rat flea which is the vector for all the above diseases except relapsing fever which is transmitted by soft ticks.

Rat fleas are vectors for:

  • Endemic typhus
  • Bubonic plague
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Fleas transmit these diseases through the bite of a blocked flea, defecation, or direct mechanical transmission. Control of the disease is done by using insecticides such as 10% DDT, repellents like diethyltoluamide, and rodent control.

Bubonic plague is caused by Yersinia pestis through the bite of infected rat flea and presents as inguinal buboes. Other types of plague include pneumonic and septicemic plague which are less common than bubonic plague.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: All of the following are associated adverse effects of captopril except:
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is not an adverse effect of ACE(angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitor.

ACE inhibitors, like captopril, and lisinopril, are associated with the development of

  • Hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia)
  • Hypotension
  • Cough
  • Dysgeusia
  • Skin rash
  • Neutropenia and

Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys leading to hyperkalemia.

The adverse effects of ACE inhibitors are:

Hyperkalemia - Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys leading to hyperkalemia.

Hypotension - A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.

Cough - It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug. In very few patients(0.1%-0.5%), ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. Angioedema of the intestine can occur very rarely.

Angioedema - ACE inhibitor-associated angioedema is a class effect, and patients who develop this adverse event should not be prescribed any other drugs within the ACE inhibitor class.

Teratogenicity - ACE inhibitors cause reduced perfusion and oligohydramnios leading to fetal growth retardation, calvarium maldevelopment, hypoplasia of lungs and kidneys, and limb contractures.

Dysgeusia (alteration in or loss of taste)

Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.

Skin rash

Extremely rare but reversible side effects include neutropenia, glycosuria in the absence of hyperglycemia, anemia, and hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: A 32-year old man from Kerala presented with a hydrocele. His peripheral blood smear image shows the following. Which of the following is the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail which is characteristic of Brugia malayi. It is endemic to Kerala (most common), Assam, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and West Bengal.

The following are the characteristic features of microfilaria of Brugia malayi:

  • Smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti.
  • Shows kinks and secondary curves.
  • Cephalic space is longer.
  • Carries double stylets at the anterior end.
  • Nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films.
  • Tail tip carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

Filariasis: In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis, referred to as Bancroftian filariasis which is transmitted by C. quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). B. malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the Mansonia mosquito.

It occurs due to the transmission of filariform larva (stage III larva), whereas, microfilaria is the larval stage that circulates in the human blood, which is ingested by mosquitoes during the blood meal. The extrinsic incubation period (duration of the mosquito cycle) is 10-14 days under optimal humidity and temperature. The reservoir of infection: humans (predominantly in India) and animals.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Diagnosis: Microfilaria can be detected in blood, chylous urine, lymphatic exudate, and hydrocele fluid. The membrane filter concentration (MFC) method is the most sensitive technique, but very low-density Mf carriers will not be detected.

Management: Use of TDT - Ivermectin + Diethylcarbamazine citrate (DEC) + albendazole. Mass drug administration is done in endemic areas with more than 80% coverage and done for 5-6 years on annual basis. The MDA is done using DEC+ Albendazole or Albendazole + Ivermectin. Management during the later phase involves the prevention of local infection and disability limitation.

Other options:

Option A: The microfilariae of Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Option B: The microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus is unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.

Option C: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is jaw-thrust. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway, particularly in patients with a cervical spine injury.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. The Jaw-thrust maneuver moves the tongue anteriorly with the mandible, reducing the obstruction of the airway by the tongue. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing as per the AHA 2020 guidelines.

Other options: 

Option A: In a head-tilt chin-lift one hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and middle finger of the opposite hand. This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat. Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury. The process is demonstrated in the GIF below:

Option C: There is no maneuver named head-extension in emergency airway management according to the BLS algorithm.

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. The fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention. This is demonstrated below:

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: A lady presents with 5-7 episodes/day of unilateral, severe headaches that typically last for 5-10 mins. She also complains of marked autonomic features during the episodes. Which of the following drug would give her complete relief?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Paroxysmal hemicrania and the episodes are completely relieved by indomethacin.

Paroxysmal hemicrania is characterized by frequent(>5 episodes/day), unilateral, severe, short-lasting(5-10 mins), and frequent episodes of headache. They have marked autonomic features ipsilateral to the pain.

Indomethacin (25–75 mg t.i.d) can completely suppress attacks of paroxysmal hemicrania. It is also effective in:

  • Hemicrania continuum
  • Primary sexual / exercise headache 
  • Tension-type headache

Other options:

Option B: Sumatriptan is used in the management of migrainous neuralgia.

Option C: IV lidocaine is used in the management of SUNCT/SUNA.

Option D: Verapamil is the drug of choice for the prophylaxis of cluster headaches.

questions.text: A group of scientists are studying gastric cancer.  They extract DNA from the cell and cleave it using a restriction enzyme. They separate the DNA fragments by running them on an electrophoresis gel. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose paper and the gene of interest is isolated by exposing it to labeled DNA probe. Which of the following laboratory techniques does this describe?
questions.solution:
The above scenario describes the Southern blot. This technique is used to detect mutations in DNA.

Procedure:

DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe (DNA, RNA, or oligonucleotides).

Variants of Southern blot are:

  • Northern blot- It is similar to Southern blot except that the sample is a mixture of mRNA molecules that are separated by electrophoresis. It is then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with a radiolabeled probe.
  • Western blot (also called immunoblots)- It is also similar to southern blots, except that the proteins are taken as samples and the probe is labeled antibody.

A polymerase chain reaction is a technique to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It uses DNA polymerases to amplify the targeted portions of the DNA.

questions.text: A young man, during a property dispute, attacked his brother with an axe. His brother sustained a 14x7 cm laceration in the left thigh and fracture of the left femur shaft. The man who attacked is punishable under which of the following section of IPC?
questions.solution:
He should be punished under Section 326.

Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapon(imprisonment upto 10 years with fine).

Section 320 of IPC states that the following kinds of hurt only are designated as “grievous”:
  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Other options:

  • Section 320 - defines grievous hurt
  • Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt).
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment upto 7 years with fine)

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought by her mother, who is concerned that her daughter has not achieved menarche so far. The history is otherwise unremarkable. You find that her breast development and other secondary sexual characteristics are normal. How will you proceed with this case?

choices.text: Delay investigations until 16 years of age

questions.solution:
This 14-year-old girl has amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics. Hence, investigations may be delayed until the age of 16 years, and the patient can be reassured.

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by 14 years without the development of secondary sexual characteristics or by 16 years regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

Investigations may be delayed in girls of 14 years in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics since delayed puberty is a possibility in such cases. However, further investigations must be done if the patient presents with any other features suggestive of a specific cause (like short stature in Turner's syndrome) or if there is the absence of secondary sexual characteristics at 14 years, or if her age is 16 years or more.

Investigation algorithm for amenorrhea:

Causes of primary amenorrhea:

  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction 
    • Kallmann's syndrome
    • CNS tumors - craniopharyngioma
    • Delayed puberty
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Primary ovarian failure
    • Resistant ovarian failure
    • 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Turner's syndrome (45 X)
    • Pure gonadal dysgenesis (46 XX or 46 XY)
    • Androgen insensitivity syndrome (testicular feminization syndrome) (46 XY)
  • Developmental defect of the genital tract
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Vaginal atresia/cervical atresia
    • Absent uterus in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)
  • Others:
    • Uterine synechiae (congenital)
    • Adrenogenital syndrome
    • Cretinism
    • Juvenile diabetes
    • Malnutrition
    • Anemia
    • Weight loss
    • Tuberculosis

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient came with a complaint of a palpable painless mass in the left breast. On examination, the mass was highly mobile and rubbery in consistency. Ultrasound of the left breast was performed and the finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with the above image is suggestive of fibroadenoma of breast. It presents as a painless, palpable lump and is rubbery in consistency. The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity. 

Fibroadenoma is one of the aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). These are the most common benign masses of the breast. The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade.

It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications).

The image below shows popcorn calcification:

Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC). Giant fibroadenomas are >5 cm in size, common in adolescent girls, and require excision by submammary incision.

questions.text: A 29-year-old  woman who is on oral warfarin therapy following mitral valve replacement has come with complaints of amenorrhoea for 8 weeks. A urine pregnancy test was done and was found to be positive. What should she be advised?

choices.text: Continue oral warfarin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then switch to heparin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy
Continue oral warfarin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then switch to heparin till 7 days postpartum
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin till 7 days postpartum
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Switch to heparin until 12 weeks of pregnancy, then continue warfarin up to 36 weeks of pregnancy. 

Warfarin, although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirth. Hence, it must be avoided in the first trimester. Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) is used. For patients taking LMWH, Factor Xa levels should be monitored weekly. 

Heparin is restarted at 36 weeks of gestation. It should be discontinued just before (at least 6 hours before) delivery. If delivery occurs before discontinuation and there is extensive bleed­ing, then intravenous protamine sulfate can be given. Heparin anticoagulation is restarted after 6 hours of vaginal delivery and is continued up to 7 days postpartum. Later, warfarin is to be continued.

Warfarin, LMWH, and UFH do not accumulate in breast milk and do not have an anticoagulant effect in the newborn. They are compatible with breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of waking up in the night and screaming for the past 4 months. The episodes were regular at around 10 pm every night, but the boy was not able to recall the episode happening and was inconsolable during the episode. He started going to school 5 months ago and had a liking for violent video games. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is where a boy who wakes up in the middle of the night screaming and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors.

Sleep terrors/night terrors/pavor noc­turnus/incubus are sleep arousal disorders that are seen in stages 3 and 4 of non-rapid eye movement sleep. They are characterised by recurrent episodes, usually occurring in the first third of the night. The disorder may be familial and is mostly seen in young children and rarely in adults.

Clinical features include:

  • The patient experiences intense fear, characterised by screaming and relative unresponsiveness to the efforts of others to comfort the patient
  • There are autonomic signs like mydriasis, tachycardia, rapid breathing, and sweating during each episode, suggestive of intense fear.
  • There is no memory of the episode, causing confusion and disorientation if awakened.
  • There may be incoherent vocalisations
  • Sleep terrors are usually devoid of any images or may contain only fragments of very brief, frightening static images.
  • There are no signs of temporal lobe epilepsy or other sei­zure disorders

Precipitants of sleep terrors can be:

  • Fever
  • Sleep deprivation
  • CNS depressant withdrawal.
  • History of a traumatic experience
  • Psychiatric issues

Treatment involves:

  • Universal sleep hygiene
  • Behav­ioral techniques
  • Stimu­lus control therapy
  • Lucid dream therapy
  • Cognitive therapy

Other options:

Nightmare disorder/dream anxiety attacks: Terrifying dreams that occur in the rapid eye movement stage of sleep. They pro­duce sympathetic activation to awaken the patient to wakefulness, where the dream can be recollected. They are commonly seen in young children and adults with post-traumatic stress disorder.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Traumatic events
  • Medications like L-DOPA and beta blockers
  • Withdrawal from REM suppressant medications
  • Drug or alcohol abuse
  • Sleep deprivation

Sleep-related groaning/Catathrenia: Chronic condition characterized by prolonged, frequent loud groans during sleep, which occur at any stage of sleep. It may begin during childhood and is not related to any psychiatric or physiologic abnormalities. There is no known treatment.

Sleep-related hallucinations: Visual images that are difficult to differentiate from dreams, occurring at sleep onset (hypnagogic) or on awakening (hypnopompic) from sleep. They are com­mon in patients with narcolepsy. They usually happen with abrupt awakening and without remembrance of dreaming. The images may be frightening, vivid, immobile and usually disappear when a light is turned on.

questions.text: A patient with HIV has a CD4 count of 170/ μL. He is complaining of breathlessness for the past 3 days. A chest radiograph was taken and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows symmetric interstitial infiltrates mainly in the perihilar region. This finding along with the CD4 count of 170 cells /μL makes pneumocystis pneumonia as the most likely diagnosis.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Other options

Option A- Mycobacterium avium complex infection is generally seen when the CD4 count falls less than 50 cells/μL. CT scan of the infected lung will show peribronchial inflammation, which gives rise to a tree in a bud appearance (small round structures attached to linear structures). In severe cases, there might be bronchiectasis and cavity formation.

Below image- Tree in bud appearance which is indicated by an arrowhead.

Option B- Histoplasmosis occurs when the CD4 count falls below 150 cells/μL and high risk populations in endemic areas or those with occupational exposure. Chest radiograph shows the signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy.

Option D- Pneumococcal pneumonia commonly appears as lobar or segmental consolidation. In some, it can involve more than one lobe. It can have pleural effusion and empyema in severe cases.

questions.text: A woman brings her husband to the psychiatry OPD. She says he is usually shy and mature. The previous week, she saw him flirting with a girl. When confronted, he said he could not recall this at all. During the fight, he suddenly started talking in a child-like voice and began to cry. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of dissociative identity disorder. It is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states. It was previously called multiple personality disorder.

The identities or personality states are called alters, self­ states, or alter identities. Each has its own pattern of perceiving and thinking about the environment and self. It is strongly associated with severe expe­riences of early childhood trauma, usually maltreatment.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with wet age-related macular degeneration is being administered ranibizumab intravitreally. All of the following are known side effects of the drug, except _______.
questions.solution:
Ranibizumab is associated with a raise in IOP, not a fall.

Ranibizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against VEGF-A (vascular endothelial growth factor-A). Ranibizumab is indicated in wet age-related macular degeneration and is used intravitreally where it inhibits VEGF-A induced ocular neovascularization.

questions.text: A 32-year-old diabetic man was undergoing a routine check-up. ECG revealed ST changes as given below. Repeated cardiac biomarkers were found to be within the normal range. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows coved ST-segment elevation of V1-V3, followed by a negative T wave (Brugada sign), which points to a diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. A coved ST segment has a downward concavity.

Brugada syndrome is an inherited sodium channelopathy (SCN5A mutation) most commonly seen in Southeast Asian males. The age of presentation is usually 40 years. This syndrome is characterised by an increased risk of sudden cardiac death due to polymorphic ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

To establish a diagnosis of ST-elevation MI (Option B) and NSTEMI (Option D), a positive and significant rise in cardiac biomarkers (troponins) is necessary along with one of the following features:

  • Symptoms of ischemia
  • New ST-T elevation or LBBB (not for NSTEMI)
  • Pathologic Q waves (STEMI, old infarcts)
  • Imaging evidence of loss of myocardium viability
  • Intracoronary thrombus identified on angioplasty or autopsy

Since we do not have a typical rise and fall pattern of cardiac biomarkers, in this case, a diagnosis of acute ST-elevation MI and NSTEMI is less likely.

Causes of ST-T changes apart from acute MI:

  • Acute pericarditis (Option C) - Diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and PR depression)
  • Brugada patterns (right bundle branch block-like pattern with ST elevations in right precordial leads) seen secondary to electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia
  • Hyperkalemia (peaked T waves)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with sudden pain in his scrotum associated with fever. His condition rapidly progressed and his scrotum appears as below. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for which he is taking canagliflozin. IV fluids are started and vital signs are noted to be stable. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image findings of cellulitis of the testis are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. The next best step in the management of this condition is IV fluids, intravenous antibiotics, and urgent surgical excision.

Fournier's gangrene - 

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. 

Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as

  • HIV
  • Alcoholism
  • Diabetes (the SGLT-2 inhibitors currently available are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin which can also cause Fournier's Gangrene)

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus can be seen as shown in the image below.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, it is also called shameful exposure of the testis. It is a surgical emergency.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. When the infection has been controlled, the vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose of 520 mg/dl and urine positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin.

Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents are never used in the initial management of DKA. 

The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions are also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease:

It is a mild exanthematous fever that usually occurs in children, but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles.

The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously.

Coxsackieviruses are enteroviruses and belong to the Picornaviridae family. They are classified into groups A and B. Group A viruses are classified into 24 types, and group B viruses are classified into 6 types.

Diseases caused by Coxsackie A viruses include -

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) 
  • Herpangina - It is febrile vesicular pharyngitis. It is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, palate, or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall.
  • Aseptic meningitis

Diseases caused by Coxsackie B viruses include -

  • Pleurodynia or Bornholm disease- It is viral myalgia defined by sudden severe lancinating pain, typically on one side of the chest. It is commonly associated with fever, malaise, and headaches. 
  • Myocarditis and pericarditis in the newborn.
  • Orchitis, juvenile diabetes

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet: 

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus causes impetigo. It is characterized by sores around the mouth and the nose and typically forms a honey-colored scab. It is more commonly seen in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles.

The image given below shows impetigo.

Option C: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a T-lymphotropic human herpes virus transmitted via saliva. It may cause roseola infantum/ sixth disease/ exanthem subitum in infants and young children. Roseola infantum is primarily caused by HHV-6.

The image given below shows typical rashes in an infant with exanthem subitum.

Option D: Poxvirus causes molluscum contagiosum in children and young adults. It is characterized by pink or pearly white wart-like nodules with central umbilication on the skin. 

The image given below shows molluscum contagiosum lesions.

questions.text: You are a physician working in the paediatric emergency department. This is the arterial blood gas (ABG) of patient X: pH = 7.5, pCO2 = 25 mm Hg, bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L. Which of the following patients does this ABG belong to?

choices.text: A 3 yr old boy with severe vomiting with blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg
A 4 yr old girl with breathlessness and respiratory rate of 50 breaths/min
A 5 yr old girl with opioid overdose and respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min
A 6 yr old boy with fatigue and drowsiness and blood glucose of 600 mg/dL

questions.solution:
The ABG shows increased pH with low pCO2 (Respiratory alkalosis due to CO2 washout). Such a picture will be seen in a child with severe tachypnoea.

Other Options:

Option A: In this case, there will be metabolic alkalosis: High pH, high bicarbonate, high pCO2. Note: The blood pressure in this case is normal for a 3 yr old child.

Option C: In this case, there will be CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis: Low pH, high CO2

Option D: In this case, there will be metabolic acidosis: Low pH, low bicarbonate, low pCO2

pH<7.35 is acidosis
