A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: The histopathological appearance of the renal arteriole of a patient with a BP of 230/120 mm Hg is as below. The fundoscopy showed bilateral retinal flame hemorrhages. The pathophysiology of her hypertension is likely due to:

choices.text: Hyaline deposition in the small capillaries
Basophilic calcification of the muscular arteries
Fatty  streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima

questions.solution:
The given scenario of severe hypertension (blood pressure ≥180/≥120 mmHg) with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages and/or papilloedema) is suggestive of malignant hypertension (also known as hypertensive emergency/crisis). The histopathological image shows fibromuscular hyperplasia of the arterioles having a typical onion-skin appearance. This is seen in hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. 

Malignant hypertension is characterized by severe hypertension with ischemic complications of multi-organs. The commonly affected organs are eye (resulting in retinal hemorrages, hard exudates, cotton wool spots with or without papilledema) and kidney (causing malignant nephrosclerosis). 

The pathophysiology behind this condition is due to hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. It affects small arteries and arterioles causing thickening and hardening of the wall with loss of elasticity. 

Histopathological features of malignant hypertension are - 

  • Smooth muscle and collagen proliferation are seen resulting in reduced size of the lumen. This further leads to concentric, laminated arteriolar thickening of the vessel wall with duplication of the basement membrane giving rise to an onion-skin appearance. 
  • They are also accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arterioles), particularly in the kidney and can lead to acute renal failure. 
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, DIC, and encephalopathy may also be present. The prognosis is very poor if left untreated.
  • No changes are seen in the heart. 
 

Other options - 

Option A: Hyaline deposition in the vessel wall leads to benign hypertension. Here, the arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is irregular and markedly narrowed. It can also cause bilaterally contracted kidneys with the renal surface showing diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather. 

Option C: Basophilic dystrophic calcification in tunica media and internal elastic lamina is seen in Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. The vessels are hardened and can be felt like bone on palpation. They are usually asymptomatic and are seen in age groups more than 80 years. Lumen size is normal here. 

Option D: Fatty streaks and foamy macrophages in tunica intima are characteristic of atherosclerosis. 

The cells marked in the image below are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.

questions.text: A 28-year old woman presented with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, and fatigue. She underwent a colonoscopy which revealed the following finding.  Which of the following histological findings is characteristically seen in the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. The presence of non-caseating granulomas is characteristic of Crohn's disease, although it is not very common. Features like crypt abscesses, diffuse inflammatory infiltrate and pseudopyloric metaplasia are common to both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 

 

Clinical features include:

  • Crampy abdominal pain that may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with the ileal disease. More extensive/severe disease will have features of abdominal obstruction
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhoea: Fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loos of bile salts, enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

It mainly affects the ileum and colon. The rectum is often spared in Crohn's disease. Gross features include:

  • Transmural inflammation: Full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel
  • Aphthous ulcers: Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers: Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Skip lesions: Involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening normal mucosa
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance: Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa.
  • Fibrosis, adhesions and fistuale due to increased inflammation

Microscopically aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses are the earliest lesions. Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas. Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas and pseudopyloric metaplasia

The image below shows transmural inflammation where inflammatory cells (neutrophils) extend from mucosa through submucosa, and to the muscularis thereby, infiltrating and damaging crypt epithelium. The normally straight and parallel crypts appear distorted. Non-caseating granulomas are seen.

 

The image given below shows cobblestone appearance as seen in Crohn's disease.

Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) are found in 75% of individuals with ulcerative colitis but only 11% of those with Crohn disease. In contrast, ulcerative colitis patients tend to lack antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which are often present in those with Crohn disease.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn disease include the following:

  • uveitis
  • migratory polyarthritis
  • sacroiliitis
  • ankylosing spondylitis
  • erythema nodosum
  • clubbing of the fingertips
  • primary sclerosing cholangitis (more frequent with ulcerative colitis)

Cutaneous granulomas form nodules are referred to as metastatic Crohn disease, a misnome, since there is no cancer.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought with complaints of bilateral knee pain. On examination, he had pinpoint ecchymoses around the hair follicles. His X-ray appears as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray image showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, Frenkel's line, and Wimberger's ring sign are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in generalized bleeding tendencies.

Clinical features:

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular hemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Radiographic features of scurvy include:

  • Wimberger's ring sign - sharp margination of the epiphysis by a sclerotic rim
  • White line of Frankel - calcified cartilage at metaphyses
  • Trumerfeld zone - a lucent zone beneath the Frankel's line due to lack of mineralisation of osteoid
  • Pelkan spurs - due to fractures at the cortical margin
  • Periosteal elevation - due to subperiosteal haemorrhages

 

Other options:

Option A: Rickets occurs due to vitamin D deficiency in children. The patients present with skeletal changes like bowing of legs and bone pain. Radiological features show cupping at metaphysis, fraying, and widening of the growth plate.

Option B: Caffey’s disease is infantile cortical hyperostosis. It usually presents at 6 months of age with painful soft tissue swelling and bone thickening. The mandible is the most common bone involved.

Option D: Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with the hallmark features of osteoporosis with increased fragility of bones along with blue sclera, dental fragility as well as hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: The  instrument shown in the image is used in :
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bonney's myomectomy clamp which is used in open myomectomy.

It has two sets of finger grips and a locking rachet mechanism.

It helps in controlling hemorrhage during the surgery. The clamp should be applied from the pubic end of the abdominal wound and round ligaments that contain uterine vessels should be gripped.

Doyen Myoma Screw is also used in open myomectomy.

Other options:

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging technique used to visualise the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by injecting a radiopaque dye.10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

questions.text: A  researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the harmful effect of UV radiation on human skin. He observed that UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA  polymerase. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms corrects this particular defect?
questions.solution:
The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA.

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Frontal image of the face, showing large hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring and injection are evident.

 

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair, leading to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As time passes these lesions become permanent. As the age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin. Since deeper structures like eyelids, cornea, and lens are shielded, are lesser affected.

XP is ultimately fatal. Early detection of skin lesions and their management (prevention of exposure to UV rays) prolongs life.

questions.text: A middle-aged man was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and was started on a drug that acts by inhibition of amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase,  dihydrofolate reductase, and inhibition of activation of nuclear factor-κB. Which drug was he likely on?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is the disease-modifying anti rheumatoid drug that increases extracellular adenosine. Methotrexate’s principal mechanism of action relates to the inhibition of amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and dihydrofolate reductase(DHFR).

AICAR accumulates intracellularly, and competitively inhibits AMP deaminase, leading to an accumulation of AMP. The AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is a potent inhibitor of inflammation. As a result, the inflammatory functions of neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes are suppressed.

Methotrexate belongs to the antimetabolite class of anticancer drugs. The antifolate action of the drug is responsible for its anti-cancer properties.

Mechanism of action:

It is a folic acid analogue and binds to the active catalytic site of dihydrofolate reductase(DHFR). This would inhibit the formation of tetrahydrofolate(THF) which is needed for purine nucleotides, thymidylate, and the amino acids serine and methionine. This would interfere with the production of DNA, RNA, and important cellular proteins.

Low doses of methotrexate are used in the management of rheumatic diseases. It is due to the inhibition of amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and thymidylate synthetase. This results in increased levels of adenosine that inhibits inflammation.

Adverse effects:

Common side effects are nausea and mucosal ulcers. Others include anaemia, leukopenia, stomatitis, GI ulcerations, and alopecia. Dose-related hepatotoxicity is also seen. The GI effects and hepatotoxicity can be reduced by the use of leucovorin (folinic acid) or folic acid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV presented with weakness affecting the left upper and lower limbs. On examination he was confused and had a temperature of 100.4°F. He had recently been treated for a Pneumocystis carinii infection. The CD4 count was 150/μl. CT scan of the brain with contrast revealed subcortical atrophy and multiple contrast-enhancing ring lesions in the cortex and subcortical areas. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

The CT scan is consistent with the diagnosis; the subcortical atrophy probably represents HIV encephalopathy. The exact cause of CNS involvement in HIV infection is largely influenced by the CD4 count.

  • Patients with CD4 counts >500/μl have benign and malignant brain tumours similar to those seen in immunocompetent patients.
  • Patients with a CD4 count of between 200/μl and 500/μl often have cognitive disorders associated with HIV such as HIV dementia and progressive leukoencephalopathy, which are not mass lesions.
  • Patients with a CD4 count <200/μl have either opportunistic CNS infections or HIV-related cerebral tumours.

Opportunistic infections include toxoplasmosis, TB, CMV and cryptococcal meningitis.

Toxoplasmosis is by far the most common cerebral mass lesion seen in HIV patients and is usually associated with multiple ring-enhancing lesions either in the cortico-medullary junction or around the basal ganglia.

Patients often have headaches, confusion and fever. Focal neurological signs or seizures are common. The other opportunistic infections rarely result in mass lesions in the absence of disseminated infection.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Primary CNS lymphoma does display some degree of contrast enhancement but it is usually nodular or patchy; however, lesions may be multiple and difficult to differentiate from toxoplasmosis. Thallium single photon emission computed tomography is useful in differentiating cerebral toxoplasmosis from cerebral lymphoma. Primary CNS lymphoma is rarer than cerebral toxoplasmosis in HIV infection. Generally, patients with multiple ring-enhancing lesions on the CT scan with mass effect are treated empirically for toxoplasma infection for two weeks with a combination of pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine. Failure of a radiological response (on CT scan) is an indication for brain biopsy to enable an alternative diagnosis such as lymphoma.

questions.text: The drug most useful in a patient with hepatic encephalopathy is:
questions.solution:
Lactulose is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy.

  • Lactulose is a laxative that acts by getting converted to short chain fatty acid in the colon.
  • These fatty acids result in decrease in pH of intestinal juice.
  • At this low pH, ammonia becomes ionized and thus cannot be absorbed.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic patient presents to your OPD with severe restlessness, palpitations, flushing, and sweating. He was started on metronidazole about 3 days back for an infection. On enquiring, he admits that he consumed two shots of whiskey after taking his medications. Which of the following medications is least likely to produce a similar reaction?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario of the patient developing severe restlessness, palpitations, flushing, and sweating following the consumption of alcohol along with his medication suggests a disulfiram-like reaction. Levofloxacin is least likely to produce a disulfiram-like reaction. 

Disulfiram is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor. It leads to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and its subsequent manifestations. So, when alcohol is co-administered with disulfiram, it causes unpleasant reactions in the patient like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

Drugs that are capable of causing a disulfiram-like reaction:

  • Metronidazole
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine
  • Ritonavir
  • Cephalosporins containing a methylthiotetrazole group like cefoperazone, cefotetan, cefmetazole, and cefamandolec

Disulfiram should only be taken after the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours. The disulfiram-alcohol reaction can occur for 1 or 2 weeks after the last dose of the drug.

questions.text: The nerve responsible for relaying sensation from the skin over the mandible and temporomandibular joint and general sensation over the anterior part of the tongue passes through which of the following foramen?
questions.solution:

The structures passing through the foramen ovale are:

  • Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins 

These structures can be remembered using the mnemonic 'MALE'. 

The mandibular nerve (V3)

  • Leaves the skull through the foramen ovale.
  • Contains both sensory and motor fibers.
  • Sensory fibers from
    • Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
    • Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
    • Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior part of tongue
  • Motor to
    • Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masseter and temporalis)
    • Tensor tympani
    • Anterior belly of digastric
    • Mylohyoid

Structure 1 is the foramen spinosum (Option D), structure 3 is the jugular foramen (Option C), and structure 4 is the foramen magnum (Option A).

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one:
questions.solution:
For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs, including at least one diuretic.

While a calcium channel blocker, beta blocker, or alpha-blocker can be part of the antihypertensive regimen, the inclusion of a diuretic is necessary for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension. The diuretic helps in addressing fluid retention which is often a significant contributor to hypertension.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. It may be related to nonadherence to therapy, obesity, and excessive alcohol intake.

In the absence of a specific identifiable cause, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists like spironolactone have been found to be most effective add-on drugs for the treatment of resistant hypertension.

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography should not be performed in patients with ________
questions.solution:
The presence of a genital tract infection is a contraindication for HSG (hysterosalpingography). 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging modality in which radiopaque contrast is injected through the cervical canal to assess the endometrial cavity, the fallopian tubes, and endocervical canal. It should be done between days 5 and 10 of the menstrual cycle, in the preovulatory phase. It is done as an outpatient procedure. Leech Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter no 14 is introduced into the endometrial cavity through the cervical os, and the contrast is injected. The uterine cavity and fallopian tubes are then visualized and X-rays are obtained.

 

 
 

 

The image below is a hysterosalpingogram of unicornuate uterus.

 

HSG can be used for the following:

  • To assess tubal patency in infertility 
  • To detect uterine anomalies, synechiae, and polyps
  • To detect incompetence of the cervical os

Contraindications to HSG:

  • Acute pelvic infection 
  • Active uterine bleeding
  • Pregnancy/ suspected pregnancy
  • Contrast allergy
  • Premenstrual phase

HSG is a safe procedure, however, complications such as ascending spread of infection, chemical peritonitis, allergic reaction to the dye, or pelvic endometriosis may occur.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is diagnosed to be sputum smear-positive for Tuberculosis. Based on further examination, a diagnosis of Right-sided tubercular pleural effusion is made. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of right-sided pleural effusion?

choices.text: Stony dull percussion note on the right side
Mediastinal shift to the right side
Tracheal deviation to the left side
Increased vocal resonance above the level of effusion

questions.solution:
A mediastinal shift to the left side is expected in the case of a right-sided pleural effusion. 

Clinical findings in pleural effusion:

  • A mediastinal shift to the opposite side
  • Stony dull percussion note over the region of effusion
  • Diminished or absent breath sounds (tubular above level of effusion)
  • Reduced or absent vocal resonance (increased above level effusion)
  • Pleural rub may be heard above the level of effusion
  • Tracheal deviation to the opposite side in case of large effusions

A similar set of findings is seen in the case of empyema as well.

The tracheal shift to the same side in the presence of pleural effusion can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Mesothelioma
  • Empyema or effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  • Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 6-year-old mentally retarded girl presents with a protuberant abdomen, short stature, coarse facial features, and cloudy corneas. Skeletal malformations include dysostosis multiplex and bullet-shaped middle phalanx. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to the diagnosis of Hurler's disease (MPS 1). Deficiency of the enzyme α-L-iduronidase that degrades glycosaminoglycans results in Hurler’s disease.

Hurler’s disease was also known previously as gargoylism (coarse facial features).

Clinical features of the disease include coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, and inguinal hernias. They also present with hepatosplenomegaly, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, and can present with hydrocephalus or valvular heart disease. These patients also have Reilly body inclusions in their leukocytes. 

The gene encoding α-L-iduronidase is present on chromosome 4. Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate are accumulated. Enzyme replacement therapy is available in the form of aldurazyme.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

  • Most common MPS: Sanfilippo >  Hunter’s and Hurler’s 
  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
  • MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
  • Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
  • MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: A metaphyseal lesion is most likely to be associated with:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, osteosarcoma is typically associated with metaphyseal lesions.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It has a bimodal age distribution. It is typically seen in the metaphyseal regions of the distal femur and proximal tibia. 

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. It usually occurs at a younger age and commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. Most tumors have a balanced (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation generating in-frame fusion of the EWSRI gene on chromosome 22 to the FL1 gene on chromosome 11. 

Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen in radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumour occurring mainly in long bones. On X-rays, they appear as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of long bones with areas of calcification within the tumour. On histology presence of "chicken wire calcification" is pathognomic.

The image below shows an X-ray with a well-circumscribed, round lytic lesion in the centre of the epiphysis of the tibia suggestive of chondroblastoma.

Adamantinoma is a rare malignant tumour. Most cases appear in the lower extremities and classically in the tibial diaphysis. It is most often seen in the second to fourth decade of life. The patient usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling. X-ray shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and on microscopy epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma are seen. Intralesional or marginal excision causes local recurrence so complete excision of the tumour is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: According to the national immunization schedule, Vitamin A is administered to an infant at what dose and along with which vaccine?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient with renal failure was diagnosed with invasive mucormycosis and was to be started on amphotericin B. Which formulation of amphotericin B would pose the highest risk of nephrotoxicity in him?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity risk is highest with conventional amphotericin B. 

Conventional amphotericin B (C-AMB) is not a lipid-based formulation of amphotericin B. Amphotericin B is insoluble in water, hence C-AMB is formulated by complexing with bile salt deoxycholate to make it suitable for intravenous infusion. Amphotericin deoxycholate is FDA approved for the treatment of mucormycosis but the rationale behind the usage of liposomal amphotericin B over amphotericin deoxycholate in mucormycosis are:

  • Less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate
  • Better CNS penetration than amphotericin B deoxycholate or amphotericin B lipid complex
  • Better outcomes than with amphotericin B deoxycholate 

Nephrotoxicity risk with amphotericin B formulations in decreasing order:

  • C-AMB > Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC) > Liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB)
  • All lipid formulations of amphotericin B (ABLC, L-AMB, Amphotericin B colloidal dispersion(ABCD)) are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to you during your rural posting as a part of a routine checkup camp to show the lesions as below. The red papular lesions do not cause him any discomfort and have been present for 6 months. His spot blood sugar is 300mg/dl. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given maculopapular lesions on the shins along with uncontrolled blood sugar point towards a diagnosis of diabetic dermopathy.

Diabetic dermopathy:

  • It presents as asymptomatic, oval, dull‐red papules 0.5–1 cm in diameter that evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and, ultimately, atrophic brown scars.
  • Binkley's spots or diabetic shin spots is another name for diabetic dermopathy. The phrase diabetic dermopathy was coined by Binkley in 1965.
  • Pathologically, there is hyperpigmentation of the epidermal basal layer, deposition of haemosiderin and melanin in the dermis, and arteriolar basement membrane thickening.
  • Diabetic dermopathy is common and is a marker for complications of diabetes such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

Other Options:

Option A: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that is seen in diabetic patients. The most likely etiology is microangiopathy. Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. The patches are initially brown and later may progress to yellow atrophic plaques.

Option C: Granuloma annulare is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin-colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Below image shows granuloma annulare:

Option D: Furuncle/ boil is caused by Staphylococcus. It is painful and usually situated in the neck area. It is pustular and later becomes necrotic and forms a scar.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the characteristic triad seen in patients with petrous apicitis?
questions.solution:
Gradenigo’s Syndrome is the classic presentation of petrous apicitis. Immobility of the homolateral soft palate (generally due to X cranial nerve palsy) is not a component of its classical triad of symptoms. 

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)- lateral rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Fever, headache, vomiting, and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated. Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.

Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

This is generally seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with severe cramping in her legs while exercising in the gym. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months. On examination, radial pulse is 88 beats/min, and distal pulses of the lower limb are barely palpable. Blood pressure is 144/88 mmHg in the right arm and 108/70 mmHg in the right leg. The obtained chest x-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and chest x-ray showing notching of ribs strongly point towards the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. According to the site of constriction, it is classified into the following types:

  • Preductal: constriction proximal to the ductus arteriosus (infantile type)
  • Postductal: constriction distal to the ductus arteriosus (adult type)

Clinical presentation of coarctation of the aorta depends on the extent of constriction and age at the presentation:

  • Infants with coarctation of the aorta may present with tachypnea, lethargy, failure to thrive, or overt congestive heart failure. Clinical signs classically worsen after the closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Adults may present with non-specific symptoms, such as headaches and nose bleeds, or claudication of the lower limbs, which is experienced as cramping pain that increases on exertion.

Coarctation of the aorta is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome.

Physical examination findings:

  • Bounding upper limb pulses (radial, carotid) and weak lower limb pulses (femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis)
  • Increased radio-femoral delay
  • Hypertension in upper limbs and increased difference in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs
  • Continuous like murmur (due to collaterals)
  • Systolic ejection click and systolic ejection murmur in the left upper sternal border (due to bicuspid aortic valve)

Radiologic findings on chest x-ray:

  • Figure 3 sign - It is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta. It occurs due to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre- and post-stenotic dilatation along the left para-mediastinum.
  • Notching of ribs - This occurs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels.
  • Dilated left subclavian artery and dilated ascending aorta

It can be diagnosed using x-ray, CT or MRI, or cardiac catheterization. It is definitively managed surgically or with balloon dilation. 

The figure of 3 sign is shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A- Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a clinical entity in which the pulmonary veins fail to enter the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium or its systemic venous tributaries. It is classified into 4 types: supra-cardiac, cardiac, infracardiac, and mixed types. On chest radiography, the supra-cardiac type shows a characteristic snowman or figure of 8 appearance.

Option B- Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis involving the aorta and the pulmonary arteries, resulting in varying degrees of stenosis, occlusion, or dilatation. It can result in diminished or absent pulses, limb claudications, hypertension due to renal artery stenosis. Chest radiograph may reveal oligemic lung fields if pulmonary artery involvement occurs.

Option C- Ebstein anomaly is characterized by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray findings depend on the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards. There is usually an enlarged right atrium, resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly, which gives a box-shaped heart appearance.

questions.text: All are indications for adrenalectomy in adrenal incidentaloma except:

choices.text: Size  more than 4cm in young patients
Lesions that grow ≥1 cm during follow up
Size more than 3 cm in older patients

questions.solution:
Incidentalomas :

  • Incidentally discovered adrenal masses on imaging studies.
  • MC tumor presenting as incidentaloma is non functioning tumor (78%).
  • Cushing’s disease, pheochromocytoma, metastatic cancers, adenomas and adrenocortical carcinoma are other causes for incidentaloma.
  • The risk of malignancy in an adrenal lesion is related to its size.
  • Lesions >6 cm in diameter have an approximate risk of malignancy of about 25%.

Diagnosis:

  • Hormonal evaluation
  • CT and MRI

Treatment:

  • Lesions that grow during follow-up are treated by Adrenalectomy
  • Nonoperative therapy, with close periodic follow-up, is advised for lesions <4 cm in diameter with benign imaging characteristics, whereas adrenalectomy is recommended for lesions ≥4 cm in size due to the increased risk of cancer.
  • A nonfunctioning homogeneous tumor of 3 to 4 cm in young patients with no comorbidities and 5 cm tumor in older patients with significant comorbidity.
  • Patients with functional tumors or obviously malignant lesions should undergo adrenalectomy.

questions.text: Injury to the nerve marked by the red arrow in the given image results in loss of which of the following sensations of the tongue?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, general sensations are carried by the lingual nerve, and the taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Hypoglossal nerve innervates all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after blunt trauma to the chest. ECG of the patient shows the following findings. Which of the following components of JVP is expected to be prominent?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Prominent x descent in JVP is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Clinical presentation -

  • Acute cardiac tamponade - Within minutes, due to trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Presents as cardiogenic shock.
  • Subacute cardiac tamponade - occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis. Symptoms include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigability.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 
  • Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of :
    • hypotension
    • muffled heart sounds, and 
    • elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent
  • ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to a decrease in end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) in a patient who is being operated upon?
questions.solution:
Fall in ETCO2 (end-tidal carbon dioxide) is seen in pulmonary emboli.

Increased ETCO2 is seen in thyrotoxicosis, malignant hyperthermia and hypoventilation.

  • Hyperthermia
  • Fever
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Pain
  • Shivering

  • Hypoventilation

  • Increased cardiac output (ROSC after cardiac arrest)
  • Hypertension

  • Inadequate fresh gas flow

  • Leak in sampling
  • Ventilatory malfunction


End-tidal CO2 concentration is assessed by capnography. Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2.

B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning

E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: USG of a neonate who is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities reveals the presence of a keyhole sign. What is the investigation of choice for confirming the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) or micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is the best imaging technique for the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves.

Posterior urethral valves occur due to result from the formation of a thick, valve-like membrane from a tissue of Wolffian duct origin (failure of regression of the mesonephric duct). This membrane courses obliquely from the verumontanum to the most distal portion of the prostatic urethra.

The diagnosis is best made during the micturition phase of VCUG in lateral or oblique views so that the posterior urethra can be imaged adequately. The following findings are seen:

  • Dilatation and elongation of the posterior urethra - equivalent of the ultrasonographic keyhole sign
  • Linear radiolucent band corresponding to the valve - seen occasionally
  • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) - seen in 50% of patients
  • Bladder trabeculation/ diverticula

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. Which of the following antibodies are demonstrated for the purpose of early diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever. It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as 'white islands in a red sea' due to erythema with petechiae. Demonstration of circulating IgM antibody provides early diagnosis as it appears within two to five days of onset of illness and persists for one to three months.

Dengue is an acute febrile disease caused by the mosquito-borne dengue viruses (DENVs), consisting of four serotypes (DENV 1 to 4), that are members of the Flaviviridae family, genus flavivirus. 

Dengue virus is transmitted from person to person by Aedes aegypti or "tiger" mosquitoes. 

The four DENV infections can be asymptomatic or manifest. The diseases range in severity from undifferentiated acute febrile illness, classical dengue fever (DF), to the life-threatening conditions Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF)/Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). 

After an incubation period of 3–15 days, classical dengue fever begins with an abrupt onset of high fever. The condition is self-limiting though debilitating with headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, petechiae rash, and leucopenia. A macular-papular recovery rash appears 3–5 days after the onset of fever, and it usually starts on the trunk before spreading peripherally. During the febrile phase, dehydration can lead to neurological disturbances and febrile seizures in young children.  

Dengue fever is sometimes referred to as ‘break bone fever’ due to associated severe muscle and joint pain or ‘seven-day fever’ since the symptoms usually persist for 7 days.

Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or DHF is associated with hemorrhagic manifestations, plasma leakage resulting from an increased vascular permeability, and thrombocytopenia. Plasma leakage is characterized by hemoconcentration (hematocrit increase of 20%), development of ascites, or pleural effusion.

Dengue Shock Syndrome is distinguished from Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever by the presence of cardiovascular compromise, which occurs when plasma leakage into the interstitial spaces results in shock. DSS is a fatal condition. Common clinical warning signs for DSS include a rapidly rising hematocrit, intense abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, and narrowed or absent blood pressure.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies. IgG antibodies can be done in paired serum samples.

The treatment of dengue is supportive management, with hydration, cold sponging, and paracetamol for fever. Aspirin/ NSAIDS like Ibuprofen should be avoided as they can cause gastritis, vomiting, acidosis, platelet dysfunction and severe bleeding. Fluid and electrolyte replacement and platelet infusion should be done for severe cases.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in labor was admitted to the hospital at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, there is infraumbilical flattening of the abdomen and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Wait and watch for the progress of labor

questions.solution:
Based on the examination and auscultation findings, the fetus is in occipitoposterior position. The most appropriate management is to wait and watch for the progress of labor. 

In a majority of cases, the occiput rotates through 3/8th of the circle, and the baby is born in the occipitoanterior position. Hence, when the diagnosis of occipitoposterior position is made, labor is allowed to proceed normally when there are good uterine contractions and a favorable pelvis.

The occipitoposterior (OP) position of the fetus is when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. It is the most common fetal malposition. It is an abnormal position seen in the vertex presentation, not an abnormal presentation. 

  • Occipitoposterior position is commonly seen in android pelvis/deflexed head.
  • The engaging diameter of this position is sub-occipitofrontal/occipitofrontal.
  • The most common type in occipitoposterior position is right OP.
  • A persistent occipitoposterior position results from a failure of internal rotation prior to birth.

Examination findings of OP position:

  • Inspection: The abdomen appears flattened below the umbilicus (infra-umbilical flattening).
  • Pelvic grips:
    • The head is not engaged.
    • The sinciput (cephalic prominence) is not prominently felt.
  • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds are heard maximally over the flanks. However, in direct OP position, they are heard in the midline.

There are three variants of OP position:

  • Left OP position (fourth position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the left sacroiliac joint. 
  • Right OP position (third position of the vertex) - When the occiput points towards the right sacroiliac joint. It is more common than the left OP position.
  • Direct OP position: When the occiput points directly towards the sacrum.

All three positions may be primary (present before the onset of labor) or secondary (develops after the onset of labor). 

Indications of cesarean section in occipitoposterior position:

  • Arrest of labor
  • Inadequate uterine contraction
  • Fetal distress
  • Other obstetrical indications

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

Among the given options, the correct one is 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-E, 5-C.

Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Sorbitol MacConkey is used for identifying E. coli O157:H7. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC) O157: H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar. The non-STEC produces pink colonies. 

An image of the Sorbitol MacConkey medium is given below- 

BCYE agar or buffered charcoal, yeast extract agar is selective for Legionella species which are nutritionally fastidious.

Composition of BCYE Agar-

  • Agar
  • ACES buffer- To maintain the pH for optimal growth
  • Yeast extract- Supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  • Charcoal- Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species.
  • L-Cysteine- It is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  • Ferric Pyrophosphate- Used as an iron source
  • Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt- Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth.

Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria. Colonies may be observed after overnight incubation.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, a female patient developed chills and severe flank pain. Her temperature is 102.4 F, SpO2 is 96%, and blood pressure is 102/80 mm Hg. There is bleeding around her IV catheter site. You notice these reactions and immediately stop the ongoing transfusion. What would be your next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer ceftriaxone 1mg slow IV infusion after a test dose
Secure a new IV line at a different site and keep it open with normal saline
Send a blood culture to the blood bank and restart transfusion with a fresh unit of whole blood
Send the blood bag and the transfusion set to the blood bank for cross matching

questions.solution:
The above clinical history suggests a life-threatening acute hemolytic transfusion reaction. The next best step after stopping the transfusion is to secure a new IV line at a different site and keep it open with 0.9% normal saline.

Acute haemolytic transfusion reaction is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction caused by the transfusion of mismatched blood. The recipient's preexisting IgM antibodies against the donor red cell antigens can cause haemolysis of the incompatible red cells transfused. The most common cause of an acute haemolytic transfusion reaction is ABO incompatibility. 

Signs and symptoms include:

  • Fever with chills
  • Flank/back pain
  • Sense of impending doom
  • DIC
  • Renal failure
  • Hemoglobinuria

In the conscious patient, signs and symptoms usually appear within minutes of commencing the transfusion while in an unconscious or anaesthetized patient, hypotension and uncontrollable bleeding, from the transfusion site, maybe the only sign of an incompatible transfusion. Coomb’s test is found to be positive and pink plasma may be seen.

Prevention of acute haemolytic transfusion reactions can be done by:

  • correctly labelling the blood sample and request form
  • placing the patient’s blood sample in the correct sample tube
  • always checking the blood unit against the identity of the patient at the bedside before transfusion.

Initial management of life-threatening acute hemolytic transfusion reactions:

  1. Stop the transfusion and keep the IV line open with normal saline at another site. 
  2. Infuse normal saline to maintain systolic BP.   
  3. Maintain airway and give high flow oxygen by mask if necessary
  4. Give adrenaline, IV corticosteroids, and bronchodilators if there are anaphylactic features. 
  5. Give diuretic: e.g. furosemide 1 mg/kg IV or equivalent if needed
  6. Notify the blood centre immediately.
  7. Assess for bleeding from puncture sites or wounds. If there is clinical or laboratory evidence of DIC, give platelets (adult: 4‐6 units) and either cryoprecipitate (adult: 12 units) or FFP (adult: 3 units).
  8. If bacteremia is suspected due to rigour, fever, collapse, and absence of a hemolytic reaction, start a broad‐spectrum IV antibiotic.
Reaction Mechanism Presentation Management
Anaphylactic transfusion reaction - occurs within seconds to minutes - Common in IgA deficient recipients due to IgE mediated reaction

- Shock
- Respiratory distress
- Angioedema

 - Stop transfusion immediately
- Give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components
Allergic/ Urticarial transfusion reaction - occurs within 2-3 hours - Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation - Urticaria
- Flushing
- Pruritus		 - Stop transfusion immediately
- Aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction - occurs within 6 hours

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

 - Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)
- Cytokine accumulation during blood storage
- More common in frequently transfused patients and multiparous women		 - Fever and chills
- Mild dyspnoea occasionally		 - Antihistamines and antipyretics
- Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) - occurs within 1-6 hours - Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs
- Increases capillary permeability

- Hypoxia
- Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

Chest X-Ray: Bilateral interstitial infiltrates

 - Stop transfusion immediately
- Supportive care
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction - can occur during transfusion to within 24 hours - ABO incompatibility (Type 2 hypersensitivity)
- Pre-existing high-affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria 		 - Fever with chills
- flank/back pain
- Sense of impending doom
- DIC
- Renal failure
- Hemoglobinuria
- Coomb’s test: positive
- Pink plasma 		 - Stop transfusion immediately
- Aggressively manage with IV fluids
Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction - occurs after 24 hours, usually within 2 weeks - Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens
- After the transfusion, an anamnestic response results in antibody production and haemolysis
- Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens		 - Mild fever
- Hemolytic anaemia
- Coomb’s test: positive
- Screening for new antibodies: positive		 - Supportive care
- Additional transfusions if needed

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The researcher may use attributable risk to express the increased incidence of asthma in the exposed children.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Other Options:

Option B: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option C: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: All of the following serve as a landmark in the intra-op identification of facial nerve trunk by the anterograde method except:
questions.solution:
The parotid duct has the buccal branch of the facial nerve in close relation to it and can be used as a landmark for a retrograde method of facial nerve trunk location, not anterograde. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid gland.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels.
  • Temporal branch

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl, who is an alleged victim of rape was brought to you for examination. On the evaluation of the stains present over her clothes following findings as shown below were noted. What is the likely specimen detected from the stain?
  • pH: 7.4
  • Florence test: Negative
  • Kastle Meyer test: Positive
questions.solution:
A positive Kastle Meyer's (phenolphthalein) test is suggestive of a bloodstain.

This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple colour indicates a positive test. 

Other options: 

Option A: The Florence test is used for the detection of choline secreted from the seminal vesicles. Since this test is negative, the sample cannot be semen.

Option C: Tests for urine samples include detecting the presence of urea, uric acid and creatinine.

Option D: Tests for saliva samples include the Phadebas test and radial diffusion by α-amylase activity on agar gel.
