  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Disclosure of which of the following information, without the consent of the patient would be considered a breach of professional confidentiality?

choices.text: Informing the nature of illness of an under-trial prisoner to prison authorities
Informing the school board about diagnosis of tuberculosis in a school teacher
Informing the nature of illness of a convicted prisoner to prison authorities
Informing the warden about a hosteler's venereal disease

questions.solution:
Informing the nature of illness of an under-trial prisoner to prison authorities without the explicit consent of the patient would be considered a breach of professional secrecy or confidentiality.

An undertrial prisoner has the right not to permit the doctor to disclose the nature of his illness to any person. If a person is convicted, he has no such right and the doctor can disclose the result to the authorities.

Professional secrecy is an implied term of contract that a doctor will keep all professional details of his patient as a secret. A doctor must not disclose any details regarding the patient without his/ her consent.

Privileged communication includes the exceptions to the general rule of professional secrecy. According to this, a doctor has a duty to disclose information about a patient, to protect the interests of the community or state. 

Examples of privileged communication include:

  • Infectious diseases to the people in contact
  • Venereal diseases to the sexual partners/authorities in charge of residential areas (hostel wardens etc.)
  • Notifiable diseases, births, deaths to the public health authorities
  • Suspected crime, like murder, assault, or rape to the police
  • Patient's own interest like suicidal tendencies, melancholia
  • Inquiry in a court of law

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with complaints of a nose bleed. Examination of the nose with a speculum reveals the source of bleed in the anteroinferior septum. The bleeding is controlled by sitting upright, bending forward, and pinching the nose. Which among the following is the artery that does not contribute to the formation of the vascular anastomosis that is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated in the Little’s area, a region in the anteroinferior part of the septum above the vestibule. It is the commonest site for epistaxis.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery, which supplies the nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

The contributing arteries of the Kiesselbach's plexus are -

  • Sphenopalatine artery
  • Greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery, which is a branch of the facial artery which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth is the first step to control epistaxis.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with severe respiratory distress soon after birth. A chest X-ray was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest is suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

CDH is a structural diaphragmatic defect with or without abdominal contents in the thorax. It allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension. The most common type of CDH is a bochdalek hernia involving the left side. They may also have a scaphoid abdomen.

Babies with CDH present with respiratory distress immediately after birth characterized by tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, and cyanosis. Auscultation of the chest may reveal bowel sounds with reduced breath sounds.

Diagnosis is done by a chest radiograph showing herniated bowel loops hemithorax, displacement of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and reduced lung space. Prenatal diagnosis can be made using ultrasonography between 16 to 24 weeks of gestation.

The immediate step in the management is to place a naso- or orogastric tube for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation. Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy.

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided. Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have a heart murmur, microcephaly, microphthalmia, cataract and deafness. Upon questioning the mother, she recalls having fever and generalised body rash during the first trimester. Which of the following is the causative organism for these defects?
questions.solution:
The newborn baby has congenital rubella syndrome and the mother had suffered an infection from rubella virus in the first trimester.

Rubella or German measles is a serious infection in pregnancy that causes abortions or severe defects in the fetus if affected in the first trimester. Transmission of the virus occurs through nasopharyngeal secretions (droplets transmission). The mother usually has a fever and generalised body rash. The rash is maculopapular in nature that begins from the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities later. The incidence and severity reduce as the pregnancy advances and is rare after 20 weeks of gestation. 

There is no specific treatment for rubella virus infection in mothers. Post-exposure passive immunization can be beneficial if given within 5 days of exposure to droplets. The incidence of this disease has reduced due to the availability of MMR vaccines. MMR vaccines can be administered only to non-pregnant females as it is a live, attenuated virus. Pregnancy should be avoided for at least 1 month after vaccination.

Triad of Gregg is seen in babies with congenital rubella syndrome. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)

Other options:

Option A: Pregnant females infected with Varicella-Zoster virus present with fever, dry cough, dyspnoea, tachypnoea and pleuritic chest pain. The highest risk of transmission to fetus is between 13 to 20 weeks of gestation. The incidence of congenital infection is almost nil after 20 weeks of gestation. Neonates with congenital varicella infection have growth restriction, microphthalmia, cerebral cortical atrophy, hydronephrosis, limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions.

Option B: Pregnant females affected with Cytomegalovirus present with infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms, that is fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis. Transmission to the fetus increases as pregnancy advances and is maximum in the third trimester. Congenital infection includes growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial (periventricular) calcifications, chorioretinitis, mental and motor deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenic purpura. Most infected neonates are asymptomatic at birth and later present with these symptoms. 

Option D: Pregnant females are more susceptible to influenza virus infection and usually develop fever and dry cough. Few studies have shown neonates to have neural-tube defects when mothers were infected early in pregnancy.

 Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:

Organism Defects
Toxoplasma

Hydro/microcephaly, convulsions, chorioretinitis, diffuse cerebral calcifications
Parvovirus Non-immune hydrops
Syphilis

Hutchinson's triad: 

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Hutchinson's teeth
  • Eighth nerve deafness

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about cephalhematoma?

choices.text: It is usually found immediately after birth
It can lead to neonatal jaundice
It usually gets absorbed within 2-4 days
It is usually located on the presenting part of the head

questions.solution:
Cephalhematoma can lead to the development of neonatal jaundice. 

Cephalhematoma is a well-defined swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is a subperiosteal hemorrhage (located between the periosteum of skull bone and the bone). It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

 

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to the rupture of emissary veins and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Epidural hemorrhage is an accumulation of blood between the dura mater and the inner surface of the skull. It results from prolonged labor or a fetal head disproportionate to the size of the mother's birth canal. It usually resolves without any complications.

questions.text: A young man presents with a painless mass in the submandibular region. On performing drainage, the discharge contained yellow granules and was foul-smelling. Microscopy of the sample showed gram-positive filamentous rods. The colonies on agar had a molar tooth appearance. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The patient presents with a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. Penicillin G is the drug of choice.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance)
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of the Actinomyces colonies.

Treatment involves surgical drainage or excision along with high doses of intravenous penicillin G over two to six weeks, followed by oral penicillin V.

questions.text: What is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image above represents the Bragg-peak effect of a proton.

The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy, therefore, allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. 

Other options:

Option A: The BOLD (blood oxygen level dependent) effect forms the basis for functional MRI (fMRI).

Option B: The Bohr effect is the loss of affinity for O2 with decreasing pH. It occurs in the microcirculation as oxygen is consumed and CO2 (carbonic acid) is released by tissues.

Option D: The Haldane effect is the phenomenon whereby increasing arterial PO2 reduces the ability of the blood to store CO2 (as Hb-bound, carbamino Hb; or as HCO3-), thereby increasing the CO2 partial pressure.

questions.text: A 42-year-old epileptic patient is posted for general anesthesia. Which of the following is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine should be avoided in patients with a history of seizures as it further increases ICP and also causes delirium and hallucinations.

Ketamine:

  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate, intracranial tension is highly raised.
  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion etc)

Thiopentone:

  • Agent of choice for cerebral protection
  • Anticonvulsant action due to the phenyl group

Propofol:

  • Decreases ICP
  • Neuroprotective

questions.text: A 13-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty after sustaining an electric injury at home. Which of the following findings is least likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lichtenberg's figures or filigree burns are not seen in this type of electrical injury. They are a superficial, thin, tortuous, fern-like pattern of erythema on the skin and are pathognomonic of lightning burns.

The image given below shows Lichtenberg's figures.

Lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution:

Joule burns are specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. These are found at the point of the entry of the current. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter. 

The image given below shows a Joule burn.

Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and the conductor. They occur due to outer skin keratin melting over a small area which on cooling fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface. The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings. 

The crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions.

questions.text: You are an anesthetist who needs to administer general anesthesia to an obese patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Preoperatively, you assess the airway using the modified Mallampati classification and conclude that the patient falls under class III. How does her airway probably look?
questions.solution:
The patient’s airway was classified as Mallampati class III, so it probably looks like image 3. Here, the soft palate and base of the uvula are seen.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. 

In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and tongue is protruded. However, it is still not proven by studies whether class 0 is a sign of easy intubation or not. 

Other options:

Option A: In Mallampati class IV, the soft palate is not visible at all.

Option B: In Mallampati class I, the soft palate, fauces, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.

Option D: In Mallampati class II, the soft palate, fauces, and portion of uvula are visible.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: An arctic explorer facing a scarcity of food resorts to hunting down a polar bear. He later develops headaches, flushing, vomiting, and desquamation of the skin. The consumption of which of the following should have been avoided to prevent this toxicity?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vitamin A toxicity. Polar bear livers should not be consumed as they can cause vitamin A toxicity and death.

Vitamin A and other fat soluble vitamins are stored particularly in the liver and adipose tissue. 

Vitamins can be broadly classified into two categories:

  • Fat-soluble vitamins: Vitamins A, D, E, K
  • Water-soluble vitamins:  Vitamin B complex and vitamin C

Properties of fat-soluble vitamins:

  • Hydrophobic in nature
  • Transported in blood by the lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons
  • Stored in the liver and the adipose tissue

questions.text: To evaluate the Child-Turcott-Pugh Score in a patient with cirrhosis, you would need to order all of the following investigations except:
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh Score or Child-Pugh scoring system. It is, however, used in the MELD score calculation. 

The variables taken into account for the calculation of the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score include Serum bilirubin, albumin, Prothrombin time, International Normalized ratio, and clinical signs suggestive of the presence of ascites and encephalopathy. 

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of survival and complications of cirrhosis, such as bleeding from varices and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. It was earlier used to provide standard criteria for listing a patient as a candidate for liver transplantation (Child-Pugh class B) but it has been replaced by the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) and Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) models for all patients with chronic liver disease.

The PELD model for children under 12 years of age, includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dl)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dl)
  • INR
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent parotidectomy presents with flushing, sweating, and a burning sensation on the left side of the face during a meal. Injury to postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves can result in this?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome, in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/ Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome):

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule. It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would have previously innervated the parotid gland.

The clinical features include sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/ taste of food.

Diagnosis is made using the starch iodine test. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.

It can be prevented by using a sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed. This will minimize the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibres. 

Treatment includes the use of antiperspirants with aluminium chloride, subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion. But is often not curative.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a healthy baby. A screening test for hearing was planned for the baby. Which of the following tests is recommended as a part of the universal neonatal hearing screening protocol?
questions.solution:
Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) is used in the universal neonatal hearing screening protocol.

Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible, or latest by 6 months of age.

In India, a two-stage screening protocol is followed according to which infants are screened first with otoacoustic emissions (OAE). Infants who fail the OAE are screened with auditory brainstem response (ABR) or Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), which is also the definitive test. All babies kept in NICU must be screened by BERA test as per the protocol.

The first screening is usually conducted at birth or before discharge. Conducting the first screening before discharge is preferred to ensure better coverage and reduce loss to follow-up. A second screening is scheduled anytime between 1–3 weeks or during the next scheduled visit at 6 weeks. 

All babies with abnormal BERA should undergo detailed ENT evaluation and hearing-aid fitting (cochlear implants) and auditory rehabilitation must be done before 6 months of age.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with a malignant lump in the breast who is undergoing chemotherapy with doxorubicin presents with raised troponin levels. Which of the following drugs could have been coadministered to prevent her present condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity and dexrazoxane would have prevented it. Doxorubicin is an anthracycline group of anticancer antibiotics.

Doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy takes two forms:

  • Acute: pericarditis-myocarditis syndrome, arrhythmias, ST and T wave changes in ECG.
  • Chronic: dilated cardiomyopathy.

Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective iron-chelating agent that is indicated for use along with high-dose doxorubicin to avoid cardiotoxicity. The exact cardioprotective mechanism of dexrazoxane is unknown and it appears not to compromise with the anticancer activity of doxorubicin.

Option A- Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation, and allergic reactions, or as part of chemotherapy regimens (to reduce nausea and inflammation). It is not specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity from doxorubicin.

Option B- Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used to rescue normal cells from the toxic effects of drugs like methotrexate.

Option C- Mesna is used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis, which is a side effect of certain chemotherapy drugs like cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: All of the following findings seen in a patient with absence seizures would help in classifying it as a typical absence seizure except?
questions.solution:
History of developmental delay is usually more likely to occur in atypical absence seizure

Abrupt onset of seizure, seizure duration~ 10 s and seizure being provoked by hyperventilation point towards typical absence seizure.

Absence seizures are characterised by sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

They are predominantly seen in children between four to ten years of age, with a decline in academic performance in school and unexplained 'daydreaming'.

The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes

  • Rapid blinking of the eyelids
  • Chewing movements
  • Small-amplitude clonic movement of the hands
Features Typical absence Atypical absence
Developmental milestones

Normal;

Increased risk of ADHD/ learning difficulties/ mood disorders

Delayed;

Intellectual disability
Seizure onset  Abrupt  insidious
Seizure duration ~10s >10s
Provoked  by hyperventilation More likely  Less likely
Postictal period Absent or brief present
associations automatism Changes in tone
Ictal EEG 3 Hz spike and wave pattern Heterogenous; <2.5 Hz spike and wave pattern
Inter-ictal EEG Usually normal abnormal

 

EEG shows generalised symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation can provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

MRI appears normal hence not routinely recommended. Laboratory investigations are not specifically useful.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizure

Sodium valproate is the first-line therapy for absence seizures in cases associated with secondary GTCS and atypical absence

Drugs like carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine and phenytoin can worsen the absence, myoclonic, tonic and atonic seizures and are therefore avoided

questions.text: Which of the following would be considered as an absolute contraindication for insertion of copper T to a patient?

An unmotivated patient is an absolute contraindication. Out of the given options, this would be the best answer.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen for the last 20 years due to back pain. The following findings are seen in his peripheral smear. Which of the following is likely to be been seen in this patient?

TIBC - Total iron-binding capacity

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia. In iron-deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding as seen in this patient, where it presents as anemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron-deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and, chronic blood loss. The cause of IDA in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth), and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

The image given below shows koilonychia:

 

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low hemoglobin level and low hematocrit. Serum levels of iron and ferritin are low while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis and, hence, hepcidin is low.

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells

The image below shows a peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells:

 

Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate raise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stains in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral, and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200 mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg of elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight (kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000 mg (for stores).

Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased

RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation for recurrent hemiparesis. The child has also had two episodes of seizures in the last six months. On examination, the child is short-statured. There is associated motor weakness. Laboratory examination shows lactic acidosis, and muscle biopsy appears as shown below with Gomori trichrome stain. What is the likely mode of inheritance of this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS). The patient presents in childhood, with classical features of hemiparesis and hemianopia, suggestive of stroke-like episodes. The histopathology of the muscle biopsy stained with Gomori-trichrome stain shows ragged red fibers. This disease has a mitochondrial inheritance.
 
In mitochondrial inheritance, if the mother is affected and the father is normal, then all their children (both male and female) will be affected. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother will not be affected.
 
The mitochondrial inheritance pattern is as shown in the image below:
The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance, as the disease is transmitted through the affected mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria.
 
The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
 
Therefore, the affected mother transmits the disease to all the offsprings (both male and female), and only the daughters of the affected mother, will further transmit the disease.
 
Characteristic features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, organs that are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation are the ones most affected in diseases due to mutations in mtDNA. These organs include central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys.
  • There are several thousands of copies of mtDNA in each mitochondrion, of which only a few copies are affected in case of mutation. Therefore, a diseased individual possesses copies of both wild-type mtDNA and mutant mtDNA in each mitochondrion. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy. 
  • The disease manifests if a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA are present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction, called the threshold effect. In most cases, this threshold effect is reached in the organs as mentioned above.
  • Also, during a cell division, the wild and mutant copies of the mtDNA are unequally distributed among the daughter cells. As a result, the expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ.

Some other clinical features of this condition are - 

  • Cortical blindness
  • Focal and generalized seizures
  • Recurrent migraine-like episodes and vomiting
  • Short stature
  • Hearing loss
  • Muscle weakness
  • The stroke like episodes in MELAS are characteristic because they do not respect vascular territories

A replapsing-remiting course is most common with stroke-like episodes leading to progressive neurologic dysfunction and dementia.

questions.text: Administration of which of the following cannot result in drug-induced parkinsonism?
questions.solution:
Amantadine is used in the treatment of parkinsonism. It does not cause secondary parkinsonism. 

Amantadine is used for the treatment of drug-induced parkinsonism as an alternative to anticholinergics. Common side effects include livedo reticularis and ankle edema.

Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring the balance.

Drugs causing secondary parkinsonism:

  • Neuroleptics (typical antipsychotics)
  • Metoclopramide, chlorpromazine
  • Dopamine depleting agents (reserpine, tetrabenazine)
  • Calcium channel blocker: Flunnarizine, Cinnarizine
  • Lithium carbonate, amiodarone, α-Methyldopa

Causes of secondary Parkinsonism include:

  • Repeated head trauma—dementia pugilistica
  • Drug-induced
  • Tumour
  • Post-encephalitic PD
  • Toxins: manganese, MPTP, carbon monoxide, cyanide
  • Vascular
  • Liver failure

questions.text: A newborn was visited by the ASHA worker of the community under the Home Based Neonatal Care until the baby was 42 days old. A total of how many visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home Based Care for Young Child?
questions.solution:
A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).

ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months. They will help promote early initiation of breastfeeding, exclusive breastfeeding till 6 months, and continued breastfeeding till 2nd year of life along with adequate complementary feeding and to ensure age-appropriate immunization and early childhood development.

ASHAs will be provided an additional incentive of Rs. 250 for completion of 5 home visits under HBYC for each young child (Rs. 50 per visit). HBYC is being rolled out in a phased manner. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done?

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.solution:
Observe the patient for 2 hours post-meal because the patient might vomit the food.

Treatment of anorexia nervosa:

  • Hospitalization: 
    • Patients with a weight 20% less than expected weight for height should be considered for hospitalization. 
    • Dur­ing a hospitalized treatment program, patients should be weighed daily, early in the morning after emptying the bladder.
    • The daily fluid intake and urine output should be recorded.
    • If vomiting is occurring, hospital staff members must monitor serum electrolyte levels regularly and watch for the development of hypokalemia.
    • Because food is often regurgitated after meals, the staff may be able to control vomiting by making the bathroom inaccessible for at least 2 hours after meals or by having an attendant in the bathroom to prevent the opportunity for vomiting.
  • Psychotherapy: 
    • Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)
    • Dynamic psychotherapy
    • Family therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Pharmacological agents are not the first-line treatment but cypro­heptadine, amitriptyline, clomipramine, pimozide, and chlorproma­zine show some improvement in these patients.
    • Trials of fluoxetine have resulted in some reports of weight gain.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal mass.  On examination, the mass was firm, non-tender and it was possible to get above it. His past history was significant for undescended testes, treated surgically. Ultrasonography showed a homogenous mass, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes. The mass was surgically removed. The histopathological analysis of the specimen is likely to show _________________

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
The clinical case points to a diagnosis of seminoma. Microscopically, it shows a fried egg appearance of cells where cells have clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (~50% of GCTs) and it commonly occurs in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). 

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells.

Option D: Islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

questions.text: Tonsillectomy is absolutely indicated in all of the following patients except?

choices.text: A child with episodes of febrile seizures secondary to tonsillitis
An adult with history of two episode of quinsy
A child with speech problems due to hypertrophy of tonsils
A child with 3 episodes of tonsillitis in the past 1 year

questions.solution:
A child with <7 episodes of tonsillitis in 1 year does not have an absolute indication for tonsillectomy.

Absolute indications for tonsillectomy are:

  1. Recurrent infections of the throat:
    • ≥7 episodes in 1 year,
    • ≥5 episodes/year in 2 years,
    • ≥ 3 episodes/year in 3 years or
    • ≥ 2 weeks of absence from school or work in 1 year
  2. Peritonsillar abscess (1 episode in a child or 2 episodes in adults)
  3. Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures
  4. Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, or interference with speech
  5. Suspicion of malignancy

The relative indications are:

  • Diphtheria carriers who have not responded to antibiotics
  • Streptococcal carriers who may be a source of infection for others
  • Chronic tonsillitis with halitosis unresponsive to medical treatment
  • Patient with valvular heart disease having recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis

It is also indicated as a part of other procedures like palato- pharyngoplasty, glossopharyngeal neurectomy, removal of the styloid process.

Contraindications:

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10g%
  • Presence of acute infection like acute tonsillitis due to increased incidence of bleeding during infection
  • Children under 3 years of age due to poor surgical risk
  • Cleft palate
  • Bleeding disorders
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease (diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension, asthma
  • During menses

questions.text: Which of the following findings of cirrhosis is not due to portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Spider angiomas seen in patients with chronic liver disease are not due to portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension is defined as the elevation of the hepatic venous pressure gradient to >5 mmHg. It occurs due to resistance to blood flow in the liver due to fibrosis and nodules of regenerating parenchyma, and due to increased splanchnic blood flow. The complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, splenomegaly, ascites, and portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Spider angiomas (also known as spider naevus or spider telangiectasias) consist of a central arteriole, about pin-headed in size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs, as shown below. They are believed to occur due to the altered metabolism of sex steroids. They are not specific to cirrhosis, and can be seen in pregnancy, and otherwise healthy individuals as well (up to 3 small lesions can be considered normal). 

 

Other findings on physical examination that occur due to inadequate hepatic metabolism of sex steroids include:

  • Testicular atrophy, loss of chest hair, and gynecomastia in males
  • Menstrual irregularities in females
  • Decreased libido
  • Palmar erythema, which is a symmetrical, bilateral, non-painful redness of palms due to cutaneous vasodilation. The center of the palm is usually spared.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing an open cholecystectomy and uses the following instrument to lift the liver up. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is of the Deaver’s Retractor. It is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. 


Other options:

A. Czerney's retractor - has two spikes on one end and a broad surface on the other. To facilitate insertion of the first mass closure stitch during closure of a midline laparotomy wound by retracting the superior or inferior edges.


B. Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.


D. Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a bakery 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is most consistent with active viral replication in a patient with chronic hepatitis B infection?

choices.text: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgM positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative

questions.solution:
Chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication has the following serological findings: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, and Anti-HBe negative.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. If HBsAg persists beyond 6 months, it is likely to be chronic hepatitis B.

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. Initially, the anti-HBc is of IgM variety, but in chronic infections, it is of IgG class.

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity. In chronic active hepatitis, HBeAg persists and anti-HBe does not appear.

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages n Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

 Other options:

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

 

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

 

Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporters (GLUTs) is primarily responsible for insulin-stimulated glucose uptake?
questions.solution:
GLUT-4 is responsible for insulin-stimulated glucose uptake.

GLUT-4 acts in the muscle and the adipose tissue for the uptake of glucose when stimulated by insulin. A pool of GLUT-4 molecules is present in vesicles in the cytoplasm of the cells which are sensitive to insulin. When the insulin receptors are activated, the GLUT-4 transporters are inserted into the cell membrane.

During exercise, the entry of glucose into the skeletal muscle increased even in the absence of insulin. This insulin-independent glucose entry can persist for hours following exercise.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic man has been prescribed empagliflozin. Which of the following processes will most likely be affected by this drug?
questions.solution:
Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor. SGLT-2 or sodium-glucose transport protein 2 is an example of a cotransporter that plays a key role in glucose absorption from renal tubule by secondary active transport. This process is blocked by SGLT-2 inhibitors, leading to renal loss of glucose and improved glycemic control.

  • A special property of the transport protein involved in secondary active transport is that a conformational change to allow Na+ movement to the interior will not occur until a glucose molecule also attaches to the transport protein. When they both become attached, the conformational change takes place automatically, and the Na+ and glucose are transported to the inside of the cell at the same time.
  • The figure shows glucose is transported uphill and Na+ is transported downhill. Energy derived from the downhill movement of Na+ is maintained by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the basolateral side.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after the consumption of the seeds shown in the image. Which of the following is the toxin present in this seed?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are those of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is one of the toxic principles of this plant.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

The image below shows the seeds of Ricinus communis.

Option B- Crotin is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.

The image below shows the seeds of Croton tiglium.

Option D- Capsaicin is the toxic principle of Capsicum annum. Consuming in large doses causes difficulty in swallowing, abdominal pain, and inflammation of the esophagus and stomach.

The image below shows seeds of Capsicum annum.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of the atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. This leads to a fixed wide split S2.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations.

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

Other options:

Option A: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is typically associated with a pan-systolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is typically associated with a harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area) with a single 2nd heart sound (S2)

Option D: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is characteristically associated with a machinery murmur.

questions.text: Based on the X-ray of the hand given below, what is the likely age of the person?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform (>10 years) but there is no fusion of the base of the 1st metacarpal (<17 years). Among the given options, the likely age of the person is <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is <17 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is >10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

  • Lunate: 3-4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4-6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5-6 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be <18 years.

questions.text: A patient was undergoing the following procedure for the removal of gallstones. However, it required multiple attempts to retrieve the stone. What is the commonest complication expected in such cases after the procedure?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. The Pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days.

Multiple attempts at cannulation, sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or history of recurrent pancreatitis and therapeutic procedures instead of diagnostic ones impart a higher risk of pancreatitis

In this procedure, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla.

It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. Minor procedures like biopsy and endoscopic stone removal can be done via this itself.

Other investigations which might cause confusion in identification are those of :

MRCP (image below)

Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiopancreatography (image below)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, who is a known case of sickle-cell anemia, presented with a history of headache, 1 episode of generalized seizures, and confusion. On examination, she was found to have papilledema and focal neurological deficits. A  contrast-enhanced CT of the head shows the following finding. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned clinical scenario, in this patient with a history of sickle cell anemia, is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis. CECT image shows the empty delta sign, which is seen in cerebral venous thrombosis.

Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is the occlusion of the lateral, sagittal sinuses or of small cortical veins (cortical venous thrombosis).

Symptoms and signs:

  • Headache - most common, with or without vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial hypertension and papilledema
  • Focal neurological deficits
  • Altered mental status
  • Coma

It is commonly seen in hypercoagulable states. Risk factors include the following:

  • Oral contraceptive pill use
  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Dehydration
  • Intracranial infections
  • Thrombophilias like antiphospholipid syndrome; polycythemia; sickle cell anemia; protein C, S deficiency; factor V Leiden mutation; and antithrombin III deficiency

Investigations include:

  • MRI Brain with MR venography is the most sensitive investigation.
  • Non-contrast CT Brain may be normal, so CECT or MRI Brain is preferred.
  • Empty delta sign is a sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) and is only described with a CECT-scan or MRI.

CECT image showing the empty delta sign in the superior sagittal sinus posteriorly, with a large infarct in the left hemisphere causing a midline shift to the right

Treatment of CVT:

  • Acute treatment: using IV Heparin or LMWH
    • IV heparin is the drug of choice in cerebral venous thrombosis. It prevents further thrombosis and reduces venous hypertension and ischemia.
  • Maintenance therapy:
    • Anticoagulation is often continued indefinitely if thrombophilia is diagnosed.
    • If there is no underlying hypercoagulable state, treatment with vitamin K antagonists like warfarin for 3–6 months may be initiated and then converted to aspirin, depending on the degree of resolution of the venous sinus thrombus. 
    • In pregnant women:
      • Anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin throughout pregnancy and till 8 weeks postpartum

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency room with profound drowsiness. On examination, he is found to have respiratory depression, with a respiratory rate of 5 cycles/minute. His symptoms are traced back to a drug derived from the plant shown below. Which of the following is the antidote to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The suitable antidote to this patient presenting with features of opiate intoxication is naloxone. The derivative drug, opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant as shown in the clinical vignette.

Toxic parts of the plant include the unripe fruit capsule and the latex juice. Active principles of opium are grouped under phenanthrenes (morphine, codeine, heroin) and benzyl-isoquinolones (papaverine, narcotin).

These drugs act on mu, kappa, delta receptors in the CNS and mediate the effects of euphoria, analgesia, respiratory depression, gastrointestinal dysmotility, and miosis. 

The antidote to opiate intoxication is a competitive opiate antagonist named naloxone which competes with opioids at their receptor sites. Dose: 0.4-2 mg IV (It may be repeated every 10-15 minutes up to a maximum dose of 10 mg).

Other options:

Option A - Flumazenil is the antidote to treat benzodiazepine (BZD) intoxication. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, flunitrazepam) are sedative-hypnotics and symptoms of intoxication include normal vital signs, sedation, diplopia, ataxia, slurred speech, and impaired motor function. Flumazenil acts as a competitive antagonist at the site of BZD action, which is the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor. 

Option C - Physostigmine is used in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity due to atropine. Atropine is the anticholinergic active principle derived from tropane alkaloids such as Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna. Toxidrome consists of features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, agitation, delirium, mydriasis, dry flushed skin, and urinary retention. Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholine esterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine concentrations in the synaptic cleft to mitigate the effects of atropine toxicity. 

Option D - Atropine is used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity due to organophosphates (DDT, parathion, malathion). Symptoms of cholinergic toxicity include bradycardia, respiratory depression, and autonomic symptoms of salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation. Atropine used in association with pralidoxime act as competitive inhibitors at the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors to neutralize the toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the boundaries of the foramen marked as 'A' in the given image?
questions.solution:
The epiploic foramen is marked as 'A' in the given image. It is related posteriorly to the inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of the T12 vertebra.

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated immediately posterior to the free margin of the lesser omentum. It is the entrance to the lesser sac from the greater sac. It measures about 3 cm in height in adults.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct.
  • Posterior – T12 vertebra, inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

questions.text: A physiologist studies normal pressure-volume changes during the cardiac cycle using the graph shown below. The occurrence of the first heart sound (S1)  would correspond to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve closure is responsible for S1 heart sound, which corresponds to point B; it marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop:

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point A to point B.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume, which corresponds to about 50 mL. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B—the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume, which corresponds to about 120 mL. This is the point at which the mitral valve closes.
  • Diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mmHg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic contraction lasts from point B to point C.
  • A point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C, the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mmHg), and then, the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point C to point D.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic relaxation lasts from point D to point A.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 mL of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is admitted with symptoms of ear pain and ear discharge, which was not responsive to topical measures. He also complained of pain while chewing. A swab was taken and cultured; the isolate was a strict aerobe, and the catalase test was positive. What is the likely etiology of his infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the laboratory findings are suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive catalase reaction. Enterococcus, Lactobacillus, and Streptococcus are catalase negative.

Catalase test: When a microbial colony is placed in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the catalase enzyme degrades H2O2 into H2O and O2. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles. People with chronic granulomatous disease have recurrent attacks of infection with catalase-positive organisms.

Catalase positive organisms:

  • Staphylococcus
  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio    
  • Nocardia
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella   
  • Enterobacteriaceae   
  • Listeria
  • Neisseria meningitidis   
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Yersinia
  • Brucella

Catalase negative organisms:

  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci
  • Lactobacillus

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/ pyoverdin. Other pigments these organisms produce include pyorubin (red) and pyomelanin (brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/ Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric, sepsis, and invasive disease
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pseudomonas is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by producing diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses, such as burns, predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Pseudomonas is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas. Biochemical tests, such as arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction, make species identification possible. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green-colored colonies are shown in the image below.

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

Oxidase positive organisms:

  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio
  • Helicobacter
  • Campylobacter
  • Pasteurella
  • Legionella
  • Neisseria
  • Brucella
  • Moraxella
  • Burkholderia
