questions.text: An infant was brought for routine evaluation. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Examination of the fundus revealed a cherry-red spot in the macula. Histopathological examination of splenic tissue is shown below. Electron microscopy shows the presence of zebra bodies. Which of the following lipids is accumulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological examination showing lipid-laden foam cells and electron microscopy showing zebra bodies are suggestive of Niemann-Pick disease. Due to the deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme, sphingomyelin accumulates in the cells.

Niemann-Pick disease is an autosomal recessive inborn error of lipid metabolism. It results due to the deficiency of the sphingomyelinase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the brain, lung, liver, and spleen.

The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, failure to thrive, severe psychomotor regression, interstitial lung disease, and a cherry-red spot in the macula. 

On histopathology, the affected cells are enlarged due to the deposition of sphingomyelin and cholesterol. They are described as 'foam cells' due to the presence of multiple small vacuoles. Electron microscopy reveals these vacuoles to be engorged lysosomes. They contain characteristic membranous cytoplasmic bodies called zebra bodies. 

Treatment includes dietary restriction of cholesterol. It is fatal in early life.

questions.text: Which test will be positive in starvation state in urine?

choices.text: Benedict test and heat coagulation test
Heat coagulation test and Rothera's test

questions.solution:
Detectable levels of ketone bodies in urine (ketonuria) are seen in conditions characterized by increased ketogenesis such as starvation. The urine test done for ketone bodies is the Rothera’s test in which formation of a purple ring indicates presence of ketone bodies. Gerhardt’s test is also done to detect ketone bodies in urine.

Benedict’ test done for reducing sugars.

Heat coagulation test done for proteins.

questions.text: You notice a meteorologist using the instrument given below. What is he trying to measure?
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is sling psychrometer (also called whirling psychrometer). It is used to measure the relative humidity.

Sling psychrometer:

  • It consists of two mercury thermometers (dry and wet), mounted side by side on a wooden frame.
  • A handle is present on one end of the frame, which allows for the rotation of the instrument.
  • By rotating the instrument, the bulbs are exposed to air at a definite velocity.
  • The wet bulb is first moistened by distilled water and the instrument rotated at the rate of four revolutions per second for about 15 seconds.
  • The instrument is rotated twice at an interval of 10 seconds. Two successive readings from the wet-bulb are obtained.
  • These readings are compared with the reading of the dry bulb, and with the help of suitable charts, the relative humidity of the air is determined.

Other instruments used to measure humidity include:

  • Dry and wet bulb hygrometer
  • Assman psychrometer

Other options:

Option A: The air temperature can be measured by several instruments such as globe thermometers, kata thermometer, dry and wet bulb thermometers.

Option C: Atmospheric pressure is measured by instruments called barometers. The commonly used instruments include Fortin's Barometer, Kew Pattern Station Barometer and Barograph.

Option D: Precipitation is a collective term used for rain, snow, hail, dew and frost. It is measured by Symon's Rain-gauge.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

  • Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).
  • Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.
  • Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.
  • The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’.
  • Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.
  • Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is this test?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the image is Roos test. It is also referred to as the elevated arm stress test (EAST). It is a provocative test for the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome.

For this test, the patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with symptoms of fever and pharyngitis following his return from a summer camp. On examination, you find signs of acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of pharyngoconjunctival fever. It is caused by adenovirus which is a non-enveloped, space-vehicle-shaped dsDNA virus.

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute highly infectious illness caused by adenovirus serotypes 3 and 7. It occurs as outbreaks, in schools, summer camps, and prisons.

It presents as fever, pharyngitis, and acute follicular conjunctivitis with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. The illness usually lasts for about 1-2 weeks followed by complete recovery.

Other illnesses caused by adenoviruses include-

  • Respiratory tract - Tonsillitis, pharyngitis, pneumonia.
  • Eyes - Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis.
  • Gastrointestinal tract - Acute viral gastroenteritis.
  • Urinary tract - Acute hemorrhagic cystitis. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. Tissue culture, serodiagnosis, and polymerase chain reaction for detection of viral DNA may be used.

Note: Adenoviruses are being used as gene delivery vehicles for cancer therapy and gene therapy. They are also used in oncolytic therapy aimed at directly killing tumor cells by viral lytic replication.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided hemiparesis and hemisensory loss of the leg and foot. He is unable to correctly identify objects, is apathetic, and has significant personality changes. The occlusion of which of the following arteries could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery is likely to be responsible for these symptoms. The anterior cerebral artery supplies most of the superior-medial parietal lobes and portions of the frontal lobes. 

Anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid artery and are part of the circle of Willis. The left and right anterior cerebral arteries are connected by the anterior communicating artery.

Anterior cerebral artery occlusion distal to the anterior communicating artery manifests as:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss that mainly affects the leg and foot, due to the involvement of the paracentral lobule
  • Inability to identify objects correctly, apathy, and personality changes due to the involvement of frontal and parietal lobes

Other options:

Option B: Middle cerebral artery occlusion produces

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss mainly involve the face and arm as it supplies the precentral and postcentral gyri 
  • Aphasia if the left hemisphere is affected 
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to involvement of the optic radiation
  • Anosognosia if the right hemisphere is affected 

Option C: Posterior cerebral artery occlusion produces contralateral homonymous hemianopia with some macular sparing (due to collateral blood supply to occipital pole. It also produces visual agnosia and memory impairment. 

Option D: Vertebrobasilar artery occlusion produces

  • Ipsilateral pain and temperature loss of the face
  • Contralateral pain and temperature loss of the body
  • Attacks of hemianopia or complete cortical blindness
  • Ipsilateral loss of gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness
  • Vertigo, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and other cerebellar signs
  • Unilateral or bilateral hemiparesis
  • Coma

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to be pregnant with 8 weeks of amenorrhoea. She has 2-year-old twins who were born at 35 weeks gestation and had one stillborn baby 3 years back at term. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score according to the GPAL system?
questions.solution:
For the given patient, the obstetric score according to the GPAL system is G3P2A0L2.

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GPAL system - 

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
  • A - Abortion - the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason before 20 weeks of gestation. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, ectopic or molar pregnancy.
  • L - Living children at present

Therefore in this patient,

  • G - 3 (The patient has 3 pregnancies in total, including the present pregnancy)
  • P - 2 (The patient has 2 pregnancies that crossed 28 weeks, excluding the present pregnancy)
  • A - 0 (The patient has no abortions)
  • L - 2 (The patient has 2 living children currently)

GTPAL system is also used which is as follows -

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • T - Term delivery, any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks
  • P - Preterm delivery, number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days. Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm. 
  • A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks
  • L - Living children at present

 For the given patient, the GTPAL score is G3(1+1+0+2).

questions.text: A 6-year-old child, weighing 20 kg presents to the emergency room with partial to full-thickness burns covering 20% of his total body surface area. As per the ATLS guidelines, the volume of fluids that need to be administered over 24 hours in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The child needs fluid resuscitation with 1.2 L of ringer lactate in 24 hours. 

According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years should begin at 3 ml of lactated Ringer’s x % TBSA x patient’s body weight in kg for second and third-degree burns. 

In this case, 20 (% TBSA) x 20 (body weight in kg) x 3 = 1200ml

Therefore, the total volume of RL to be given is 1.2 litres.

Note:

The superficial/1st-degree burns are not considered for the formula. Only the % TBSA of 2nd and 3rd-degree burns is calculated for the formula.

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain a fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text:
Ultrasound of a pregnant female showed a snowstorm appearance and enlarged ovaries with theca lutein cysts. She is scheduled to undergo suction and evacuation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

hCG - Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

choices.text: Theca lutein cysts do not require specific management apart from suction evacuation of the mole.
She should be followed up at weekly intervals till hCG values become normal.
p57 is strongly expressed in the tissues involved.
She should be advised to use contraception during the follow-up period.

questions.solution:
The USG showing a snowstorm appearance is characteristic of a complete mole. The p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

p57 is used for immunohistochemical staining. It is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed. This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele. Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. The patient presents with a characteristic history of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or spotting, and vomiting during the first trimester. Also, there may be a history of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. On examination, the size of the uterus is larger for gestational age and the fetal heart sounds are absent.

A USG scan shows a snowstorm appearance which is characteristic of a complete mole.

Suction and evacuation is the treatment of choice. Hysterectomy is done only if there is uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during surgical evacuation or if the age of the patient is above 35 years and has completed her family.

Serum hCG levels are checked after 48 hours of evacuation and are used as a baseline for future comparisons.

The patient is routinely followed up to watch for the malignant transformation of this condition. During every follow-up visit, a history of irregular vaginal bleeding and breathlessness or hemoptysis is asked for. The abdomen is checked for uterine involution and regression of theca lutein cysts of ovaries. Also, serum or urine hCG is checked at every visit and is compared with the baseline value obtained previously.

Other options -

Option A: Theca lutein cysts usually regress within 2 months of evacuation and hence require no specific or additional management.

Option B: The serum hCG levels are checked every week till it normalizes, which usually takes around 4 to 8 weeks. After the hCG values return to normal, a regular follow-up is done monthly for 6 months. 

Option D: The patient is advised to use contraception to avoid pregnancy during this period as the new pregnancy interferes with the follow-up of hCG values. 

 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A 25-year old man was found to have drug-resistant tuberculosis and was started on a shorter MDR regime lasting for 9 months. Which of the following drugs will not be continued till the 9th month?
questions.solution:
Moxifloxacin, Pyrazinamide, Clofazimine and Ethambutol are the four drugs that are continued till 9 months in shorter MDR regime.

Shorter MDR-TB regimen of 9-11 months for rifampicin-resistant TB is a recent update in NTEP guidelines. 

 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: While calculating the ankle-brachial pressure index for patients with peripheral vascular disease using the formula X/systolic pressure of the brachial artery, what is taken as the value of 'X'?

choices.text: Highest of systolic pressure of dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial or peroneal arteries
One-third of the systolic pressure of dorsalis pedis artery
Two third of the systolic pressure of  posterior tibial artery
Sum of systolic pressures of peroneal and dorsalis pedis arteries

questions.solution:
The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the ipsilateral arm. The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery. The brachial systolic pressure in the ipsilateral arm is the denominator.

Interpretation:

  • >0.9 – Normal
  • <0.9 – Claudication
  • <0.5 – Rest pain
  • <0.4 – Imminent necrosis (Critical Limb Ischemia)

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) - 

PAD presents as intermittent claudication, which is pain that increases with walking and may sometimes present with rest pain. It is generally caused by atherosclerosis but may also be due to trauma. The initial investigation done is an ABPI. Physical exam findings include atrophied skin, pallor on raising leg (Buerger's test), nail changes, and decreased peripheral pulses.

 

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A new test called DIVE has been developed to identify deep venous thrombosis(DVT). In the study, 60 patients with a positive DIVE actually had DVT and 40 patients with a negative DIVE also had a confirmed DVT. 300 patients who actually did not have DVT also had a negative DIVE test but 100 patients with a positive DIVE actually did not have DVT. What is the specificity of the DIVE test?
questions.solution:
The specificity of the test is 75%

  • 60 patients with a positive DIVE actually had DVT - True Positive
  • 40 patients with a negative DIVE also had a confirmed DVT - False Negative
  • 300 patients who actually did not have DVT also had a negative DIVE test  - True Negative
  • 100 patients with a positive DIVE actually did not have DVT - False Positive

To start calculating this question, one has to draw the table and insert the values into the table.

 

 

  Disease present  Disease absent
Test +ve 60 100
Test -ve 40 300

 

Specificity = 300/(100+300) = 0.75 or 75%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with painful blisters over oral mucosa and genital areas. She gives a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Points in favor:

  • 40-year female
  • Painful blisters over oral mucosa and genitalia
  • Suprabasal split 
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg3 > Dsg1

Option A: Dermatitis Herpetiformis

Here there will be extremely pruritic vesicular eruptions over extensors.

Immunofluorescence shows Granular IgA deposits along with the dermal papillae.

Option C: Bullous pemphigoid

  • It usually affects elders (60-80 years).
  • Tense subepidermal blisters will be present.
  • No mucosal involvement (unlike pemphigus vulgaris).
  • Immunofluorescence: Linear IgG deposits.

Option D: Pemphigus foliaceus

  • No mucosal involvement.
  • Subcorneal blisters are seen.
  • Immunofluorescence showing "Fishnet appearance" of IgG antibodies against Dsg1.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with dermatophytic infection. A scraping from the lesion was taken and observed under the potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount. It reveals the macroconidia of the dermatophyte as shown in the image. The species of this genera usually infects
questions.solution:
The image shows thin, elongated macroconidia with blunt ends (pencil-shaped) which are the features of trichophyton. The species of this genera infects Skin, Hair, and Nails.

Dermatophytes includes 3 genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton.

  • Trichophyton species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. They infect skin, hair, and nails. 
  • Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (Not Nails).
  • Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton. It infects only skin and nails (Not hair).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl child is brought with a history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Examination reveals darkening around both eyes, proptosis, and rapid jerky eye movements. There is a palpable abdominal mass with abdominal distention. Laboratory examination shows hypokalemia. The mass is excised and histopathological examination shows a small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of neuroblastoma. The child presents with abdominal pain and a mass. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic Homer-Wright pseudorosettes which point towards the diagnosis. The diarrhoea, hypokalemia and ocular features in this patient are a result of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this condition. This tumor arises from the adrenal glands and urinary catecholamines may be used to diagnose and monitor this tumour.

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumours in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. There has been an association established with fetal alcohol syndrome, neurofibromatosis, fetal hydantoin syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.

Genetics - Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The N-MYC gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favourable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Clinical features:

Approximately two-thirds of the cases arise in the abdomen and most of these cases arise from the adrenal glands. Other sites include the organs of ZuckerKandl, posterior mediastinum, pelvis, head, and neck. 

The symptoms associated with this condition are -

  • abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
  • Pain - abdominal pain or localized back pain or bone pain
  • constipation
  • proptosis
  • periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbital metastases)
  • Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis)
  • weakness (from spinal cord compression)
  • scoliosis
  • bladder dysfunction
  • palpable non-tender subcutaneous blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • secretory diarrhea (from paraneoplastic production of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide [VIP])
  • systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss)
  • anemia
  • heterochromia iridis (different colors of the iris or portions of the iris)
  • hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines
  • unilateral nasal obstruction

Paraneoplastic syndrome:

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome - It occurs in about 1-3% of patients with neuroblastoma. The characteristics symptoms are rapid, dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking (myoclonus) involving limbs or trunk, and/or ataxia.
  • Secretion of VIP - It causes abdominal distention and intractable secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia. Serum VIP levels will be >75 pg/ml

Classification: Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

Diagnosis:

  • Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. A biopsy will show the presence of small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.
  • Other investigations that would aid in the diagnosis include CBC, urinary catecholamine excretion, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, nuclear imaging with an I-131 MIBG scan, and CT to detect metastasis.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor, chemotherapy, and radiation. The tumors which have spread to other places will require surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Important chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, cyclophosphamide, topotecan, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and etoposide. 

An image of histopathology of neuroblastoma is shown below.

 

Nephroblastoma:

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs. On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Rhabdoid tumour of the kidney:

Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney is the most aggressive and lethal childhood renal tumor and accounts for 2% of renal tumors.

Rhabdomyosarcoma:

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumor. The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests Rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) generally. But, the histopathology would show elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle different stages of embryogenesis with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of RMS

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into 4 major subtypes

    1. Embryonal: Makes up 80% of orbital rhabdomyosarcomas and presents most commonly in young children (mean age 7-8)
    2. Alveolar subtype exhibits small, round, densely appearing cells that are loosely arranged, with septae that are similar to the alveoli of the lung; carries the worst prognosis
    3. Botryoid - variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; subepithelial grape-like aggregates of tumor cells; seen most commonly in infants.
    4. Pleomorphic

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin and myoglobin

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastase

 

Note:

Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extracranial) solid tumor of childhood.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on computed tomography (CT), but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student comes to the clinic with a history of four episodes of arthritis involving large joints and was recently admitted for new-onset atrial fibrillation. A holosystolic murmur with early diastolic rumbling is heard at the apex. An early diastolic murmur is also heard at the right second intercostal space near the sternal edge. Which of the following is recommended for long-term prophylaxis of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features and a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Monthly penicillin G injections are recommended for long-term prophylaxis.

The findings of mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation indicate the diagnosis of ARF. The presence of atrial fibrillation indicates severe rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis with either oral phenoxymethylpenicillin (250 mg twice daily) or preferably, benzathine benzylpenicillin (1.2 million U IM monthly) is considered the best method to prevent further episodes of ARF, and therefore prevent further valvular damage.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs.

Other options:

Option A: Glucocorticoids are recommended at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg per day (maximum, 80 mg), usually for a few days or up to a maximum of 3 weeks.

Option C: Doxycycline is not a first-line agent for group A Streptococcus, the pathogen that causes ARF.

Option D: Daily aspirin is the treatment of choice for the migratory arthritis of large joints and fever which are common manifestations of ARF.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a painless lump in the right breast. She is being planned for mastectomy and the surgeon is also considering for an additional procedure shown in the image below. In which of the following tumor stages is the given procedure indicated?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera and is done only on node-negative tumors, hence T1 N0 M0 is the correct option among the following. 

The sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. SLNB was first described in penile cancer by Cabana. 

Methylene blue dye or radioisotope i.e., technetium-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera). The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed. 

Note: The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes. Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabelled dye.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with itching and a rash on his torso. He also complains of a chronic cough with sputum production and mucoid diarrhea. Examination findings are shown in the image given below. Blood investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia and raised serum IgE levels.  Larva currens is suspected. What is the preferred treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple erythematous tracts in the skin is suggestive of larva currens caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. The preferred treatment for this condition is ivermectin.

S. stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. It has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil by feeding on bacteria. 

Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. From here, they enter the venous circulation and travel to the right side of the heart and the lungs. Within the lungs, they traverse the capillaries, enter the larynx, migrate up, and are swallowed in the pharynx. Ultimately, they end up in the gastrointestinal tract. 

The female worms lay eggs in the mucosa leading to the release of rhabditiform larva. The larvae then migrate to the lumen of the intestine and are released in feces. They may transform into filariform larvae while transiting through the gastrointestinal tract which then penetrates the mucosa leading to autoinfection. 

The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

Clinical manifestations can be grouped as follows: 

  • Cutaneous manifestations: 
    • Dermatitis is characterized by pruritus and erythema. This occurs at the site where the larvae penetrate the skin. 
    • Larva currens or racing larvae are characterized by multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae
  • Pulmonary manifestations are characterized by bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma. 
  • Intestinal manifestations are characterized by mucoid diarrhea, protein-losing enteropathy, and paralytic ileus. 
  • Hyperinfection occurs in immunocompromised individuals due to extensive autoinfection and worm load. 

Diagnosis of Strongyloides infection is by the wet mount of stool showing rhabditiform larvae or aspirates of sputum, jejunum, or duodenum. Peripheral eosinophilia and IgE may be raised. 

The image given below shows the rhabditiform larvae.

Treatment involves ivermectin (200 mcg/kg/day for 2 days) or albendazole (400 mg/day for 3 days).

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the peripheral smear of a patient with suspected leukemia. All of the following features are suggestive of a myeloblast except:
questions.solution:
Pelger-Huet anomaly is not a feature of myeloblasts. Auer rods and Phi bodies are considered pathognomonic of AML.

Myeloblasts have the following characteristics as shown in the following image:

  • Large, uniform population of cells
  • Prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow in the image)
  • Primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods - needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by fusion of lysosomes (black arrow)
  • Phi-bodies - fusiform or spindle-shaped rods similar to Auer rods that require special stains for hydroperoxidases
  • Pseudo-Chediak-Higashi syndrome - Giant lysosomes forming intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to neutrophils with bilobed nuclei that occur as a benign, inherited condition. Pseudo-Pelger-Huet anomaly refers to an acquired defect seen in CML, myelodysplastic syndrome. 

Note: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder with abnormal lysosomal trafficking (LYST gene). Presents with oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents to the OPD with symptoms of pain in both the knees since the past two years. She has been on calcium and vitamin D supplementation and is doing regular physical exercise. X-ray of the knee joint showed the following. Which would be the first line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Bisphosphonates are used in the first-line management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. X Ray shows periarticular osteopenia around the knee joint.

Bisphosphonates are analogs of pyrophosphate. They specifically inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Mechanism of action:

Bisphosphonates concentrate at sites of active remodeling. They remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Other Drugs:

  • Denosumab - This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate - It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with complaints of loss of libido and weakness. Physical examination revealed coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands. MRI showed a pituitary mass. Which of the following screening tests would you order to diagnose the cause of the mass?
questions.solution:
The screening test to diagnose the cause of the mass would be serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels.

The clinical features (loss of libido, weakness, coarse facial features, frontal bossing, and enlarged hands) are suggestive of acromegaly caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumour. However, since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

  • Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours
  • Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

Other options:

24-hour urinary-free cortisol and ACTH levels are useful in screening for Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 40-year-old taxi driver presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the attitude of the limb that you would have seen in the examination, considering the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis of the condition given in the X-ray is posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. On physical examination, the affected limb will be adducted and internally rotated, which is also evident in the X Ray.

The radiograph in left posterior hip dislocation will have the following findings:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The left femoral head appears slightly smaller than the right femoral head
  • The limb is adducted and internally rotated, and hence the lesser trochanter is often obscured/less prominent on AP view.

Posterior dislocation of the hip joint commonly occurs with the dashboard injury. It is more common than an anterior hip dislocation. Shortening of the limb is seen in the posterior type.

As the sciatic nerve lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum, it may be damaged with posterior dislocation of the hip.

Methods of closed reduction for posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Allis manoeuvre
  • Stimson manoeuvre
  • East Baltimore lift manoeuvre
  • Bigelow manoeuvre 

In the majority of the cases of posterior hip dislocation, within 6 hours, a closed reduction under general anaesthesia is performed. However, if the reduction is not achieved after two or three attempts, or a CT scan shows the presence of intra-articular bone fragments or larger femoral headpieces that are incompletely reduced, open reduction should be performed.

questions.text: A 2-week-old female baby was brought to the clinic with mucopurulent discharge from both eyes. On examination, the eyelids appear swollen and the conjunctiva is erythematous. PCR done on the conjunctival scrapings detected Chlamydia trachomatis.  What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette with the time of presentation of symptoms is strongly suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition among the given options is oral erythromycin. 

Ophthalmia neonatorum or neonatal conjunctivitis can be considered as conjunctivitis that develops within the first month of life. The causative agents are Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, Haemophilus influenzae, herpes simplex virus, streptococci, staphylococci, and chemical causes.

Chlamydia is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries and neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis is caused by serotypes D to K.

Clinically, Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion conjunctivitis manifests relatively late, usually over one week and up to three weeks after birth with a mucopurulent discharge, and swelling of the eyelids as shown below.

Diagnosis is usually established by PCR. Conjunctival scrapings may be used to perform a PCR. 

The treatment includes oral erythromycin for two weeks. Topical erythromycin to tetracycline ointment may also be used. 

Other options-

Option A: IM or IV ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. It usually presents within the first week of life and is characterized by copious hyperpurulent discharge and severe eyelid edema. Supportive management may include saline irrigation to clear the copious discharge. 

Option B: IV acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex viral conjunctivitis which presents in one to two weeks with a watery discharge. It is characterized by eyelid and periocular vesicles. A corneal examination may reveal dendritic or geographic epithelial lesions. 

Option D: 1% topical silver nitrate was used as a prophylactic measure to prevent gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. However, it is an irritant and causes chemical conjunctivitis in the first few days of life. Hence, conservatively treatment with supportive measures such as artificial tears is preferred.

questions.text: A woman with a history of 2 abortions undergoes an HSG which shows the presence of a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to the given condition?
questions.solution:

The derivatives of the paramesonephric (Mullerian) ducts in the female include

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
questions.solution:
In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane.

Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergency life-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre. Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy.

Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. Hence, statement 2 is correct. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period.

The image below depicts how finger-feeding is done.

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm infants (32-34 weeks) and term infants for supplementation. It can be for short or long-term use. It is a useful measure in low-medium income countries and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. The oro-motor movements are different as compared to that of breastfeeding. It is not indicated for very preterm infants.

Feeding tubes i.e. orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants (28-31 weeks) with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It is an expensive measure as it requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration with immature suck-swallow-breathe coordination.

BFHI is a global effort (sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund) to promote breastfeeding. It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding. The ten steps are attached in the pearl below.

World Breastfeeding Week is celebrated every year from 1 to 7 August to encourage breastfeeding and improve the health of babies around the world.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male patient presented with complaints of diminished vision. The optical coherence tomography (OCT) image is given below. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen on fundus fluorescein angiography of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). Fundus fluorescein angiography image is likely to show a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) in CME.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. A petaloid pattern is seen due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer.

Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity and topical prostaglandins. Macular edema and cysts may also occur due to niacin toxicity (vitamin B3).

Clinical features in the initial stage include minimal to moderate vision loss. Usually, there are no other associated symptoms. In case of persistent edema, permanent vision loss may occur.

OCT reveals a loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  "honeycomb appearance". Optic disc swelling may be seen in some cases. A lamellar hole may occur in long-standing cases.

The image below shows the flower petal pattern in CME.

 

Other options:

Option B: A smokestack appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

 

Option C: Stars in sky appearance is seen in drusens

 

Option D: Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance is a small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of recurrent pregnancy losses. She has had 4 spontaneous abortions, all of them at <10 weeks of gestational age, and has a history of deep vein thrombosis. The presence of which of the following antibodies is not included in the laboratory criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
The antinuclear antibody is not included in the laboratory criteria for the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

Recurrent pregnancy loss is a term used for three or more consecutive spontaneous abortions of the fetus before 20 weeks of gestation. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. The antiphospholipid antibodies cause inflammation, thrombosis, and abnormal placentation leading to recurrent miscarriage, usually before 10 weeks of gestation. 

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion and must be positive on 2 or more occasions 12 weeks apart.

  • Clinical criteria
    • Obstetric
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular: one or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue 
  • Laboratory criteria
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Treatment:

  • Low-dose aspirin (60-80 mg/day)
  • Unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin

 These drugs are started at the time of diagnosis and are given until 6 weeks postpartum.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man undergoes renal transplantation. Within minutes of completing the anastomosis, the transplanted kidney appears cyanotic & mottled, and it is found to be completely anuric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Hyperacute rejection. Hyperacute rejection occurs when preformed anti-donor antibodies are present in the circulation of the recipient.

Hyperacute rejection:

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi.
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction). Hence the transplant appears cyanotic & mottled.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:
questions.solution:
The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The costal margin, xiphoid process, and the mid-clavicular line are seen in this image. The examiner draws a laterally convex line that extends from a level below the 2nd costal cartilage (as clued in by the sternal angle) i.e., 3rd costal cartilage to about 3 spaces below i.e., the 6th costal cartilage. This line is about 1.2 cms lateral to the sternal edge. These suggest that the region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

The projection of the cardiac borders, of an average adult, onto the anterior thoracic wall forms a trapezoid.  This can be mapped out using the percussion method by looking for cardiac dullness. 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

  • Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1–2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.
